title: call-extend-20mph-limit-past-seton-sands
story: East Lothian Council has introduced lower speed limits in many towns and villages ndash including Cockenzie and Port Seton ndash as part of a project to make the streets safer for pedestrians and the increased number of cyclists who are being seen out and about.It is also creating a temporary cycle path between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans which will run along the north side of the B coast road.Community councils in these areas have welcomed these changes, which were announced after the local authority received pound.million in funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People initiative.However, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council has called for its mph road speed limit to be extended to include the section of the B at Seton Sands Holiday Village, to the immediate east of Port Seton, which has been the scene of tragic road accidents in the past.Bryan Hickman, community council chairman, said while some concerns had been raised on social media about the money being spent on measures and their temporary nature, the majority of people commenting supported the changes.He said: ldquoMost people, including the community council, are in agreement. Any work that makes the roads safer for pedestrians and cyclists must be welcomed and supported.ldquoIt is felt, however, that the mph zone needs to be extended beyond Seton Sands holiday camp.ldquoThis stretch of road is very prone to speeding and has had a number of accidents, some unfortunately fatal.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said they, along with neighbouring community councils in Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry, had been campaigning for lower speed limits around their communities.And he said the introduction of the three-metre wide cycle lane on the coast road would be welcomed by cyclists and motorists alike.He said: ldquoWith the huge increase in cyclists on our local roads and shoppers having to queue on pavements measures aimed at slowing the speed of traffic in the town are to be welcomed.ldquoThe three community councils in the Preston Seton Gosford ward have been campaigning to get speed limits lowered on the roads around the local towns and villages and hopefully this will also be introduced by East Lothian Council.ldquoThe dedicated cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie will be particularly welcomed by local children who have taken to their bikes during the pandemic. The two-way cycle path will also be appreciated by motorists who have been getting frustrated at the signicant increase of cyclists using the coast road.Additional plans under Spaces for People include installing, in the autumn, electric bike hire stations featuring eight e-bikes at two locations in Prestonpans and one in Cockenzie in autumn.

title: broadband-improvements-lined-towns
story: Openreach wants to make ultra-reliable and gigabit-capable full fibre broadband available to places throughout Scotland, including Cockenzie and Port Seton, Prestonpans, Tranent, Belhaven and Dunbar.It is hoped having access to some of the fastest broadband speeds in Europe will boost post-Covid economic recovery.Robert Thorburn, Openreachrsquos partnership director for Scotland, was pleased to see work progressing.He said: ldquoWersquove already upgraded hundreds of thousands of homes and business across Scotland to full fibre.ldquoAs well as keeping the existing network running throughout the Covid- crisis, our engineers have, safely and with social distancing in place, continued building the new infrastructure to make sure that as lockdown restrictions ease, our network is there to support families, businesses and the economic recovery.Work is expected to get under way in many of the announced locations within the next - months, although, due to the size of the build, some places will see work continue into .Paul Wheelhouse MSP, the Scottish Governmentrsquos connectivity minister, said: ldquoDigital Connectivity has played a vital role in supporting our efforts to keep people safe and connected during lockdown, and will play a pivotal role in plans for our strategic economic recovery from the pandemic, maintaining jobs and livelihoods and creating new skills and opportunities.ldquoThis rollout of gigabit-capable full fibre broadband access enabled by Openreach to these more rural areas is welcomed.To view the full list of market towns and villages included in the announcement, go to www.openreach fibre-broadband

title: changes-planned-high-street-scotmid-store
story: The High Street supermarket is looking to make changes inside its store, while also increasing the number of spaces in the neighbouring car park.Proposals for the store and car park are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A spokeswoman for the business said they had discussed the project with the local community council ahead of submitting the planning application.She said: ldquoThe work being proposed will help improve our offer in the community by improving the store entrance and external appearance of the store and by refitting the store in accordance with our latest branding.ldquoWe also recognise the limitations of the existing car park and propose to make our car park larger and easier to access.ldquoWe also propose to move the funeral unit which is located in the car park into the main building.The number of spaces in the car park will nearly double as it increases from  to .Some work has already been carried out inside the store, with energy efficient refrigeration cabinets with doors installed.

title: preston-athletic-players-swap-boots-bicycles-fundraiser
story: Members of Preston Athletic FCrsquos squad got on their bikes to raise money for the club and the NHS on Saturday, August .A dozen players, as a relay team, cycled from Dunbar Unitedrsquos New Countess Park through East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh before reaching the finish line at their home ground, the Pennypit.Kai Austin was among those setting off from the Seasidersrsquo ground at about am but had to make a quick substitution before kick-off.He said: ldquoI had not checked my bike for about a week beforehand.ldquoI was putting it into the car and noticed the back tyre was flat.ldquoI thought we would pump it up when we got there.ldquoAfter we arrived, my girlfriend drove away and I was walking along and noticed the tyre was flat again.Fortunately, one of Kairsquos team-mates for the cycle had a spare bike and they were quickly able to get on the open road.The fundraiser came about with players deciding to visit  football grounds ndash the home of  teams ndash ahead of the   season.The first stop was at Millfield , before going on to Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The second group of cyclists ventured into Midlothian and ticked off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Parkand Ferguson Park .Nathan Stokes, who plays in midfield and up front, was among the third group, who completed the Midlothian section by travelling on to Penicuik Park .Then it was into the Capital and Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosureand Christie Gillies Park .Finally, the Edinburgh section was complete with a visit to Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand Peffermillbefore ing to East Lothian and Olivebankand the Pennypit.Nathan, , said: ldquoTo get to Peffermill, we came down Cameron Toll.ldquoFrom the Commonwealth Pool, it is all downhill and by that point my legs were screaming.ldquoFor me, it was a nice relaxing run down there and when we reached Peffermill we knew it was only  minutes to Musselburgh and then another - minutes to the Pans. Getting to East Lothian was definitely a psychological boost.The cyclists finished at the Pennypit shortly after pm, where they were met by the participants from the earlier legs.Right-back Kai, who lives just metres from the ground in Prestonpans, was among those at the finish line. He said: ldquoWe had the people that did the cycle and some people there that were not able to do it because of injury.ldquoThe club put on a socially distanced get-together and put on some sausage rolls and pies.ldquoWe were sitting in the stand and were there for them arriving and cheered them in.Nathan, of Wallyford, was delighted to reach the finish line, with the cyclists completing  kilometres over the eight hours.He added: ldquoThe aim was to get pound, and then we raised pound,.ldquoWe are really chuffed and ideally I would like to raise another pound so the cash is split into pound each.ldquoI think I was chuffed and on Saturday Hearts tweeted us and wished us luck.ldquoWe have got a few Hearts fans in the team so they were happy.To support the good cause, go to justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: paralympian-maria-lyle-takes-presenting-role-podcast
story: Maria Lyle is not hanging up her running spikes but has teamed up with journalist Gary Heatly to create This Ability Podcast.The monthly show sees the duo chat with a iety of guests about what it is like living with a disability and shines a light on some amazing achievements.Maria, who has spastic diplegic cerebral palsy, said: ldquoIt is something that I have never done before.ldquoGary approached me with the idea of doing it and highlighting how disabled people live their lives and to make it come across that a disability is not such a negative thing. It is something new and I have really enjoyed it and learning from Gary.The third episode of the podcast is being recorded this month.Each episode has been created during the coronavirus pandemic lockdown, with Gary, Maria and their guests in separate locations and speaking over Zoom.The first episode featured Maria, who lives in Dunbar, and Gary, who is based in Edinburgh, discussing their own personal experiences of living with cerebral palsy.Then, last month, the hosts spoke to actress Amy Conachan, who has appeared in more than  episodes of Hollyoaks as Courtney Campbell.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Maria said: ldquoShe was really nice and friendly. It was interesting to hear her story about acting and her journey to television, which has been very successful, and how she deals with her disability.Mariarsquos love of athletics began when she was at Dunbar Primary School, with her mum, Susan, taking a PE lesson.She previously said: ldquoOne day, when I was in about primary four, we had a multi-stage fitness bleep test-type thing to do.ldquoI wasnrsquot any good at anything and everything and I wasnrsquot looking forward to it at all ndash even though my mum was the teacher. Running at that stage usually ended with me falling over  per cent of the time and cutting my knees.ldquoBut I thought I would have a go and basically I was the last pupil standing at the end of the test.Since then, she has won medals at the Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro in  and two gold medals at the World Para Athletics Championships in Dubai last year, in the T m and m.The -year-old was due to represent Great Britain at the Paralympics in Tokyo this month before the international event was put back a year due to the coronavirus.She said it was nice to speak to people outside the sporting world about their lives and was looking forward to welcoming more guests onto the podcast.Gary, , who was previously editor of The SCRUM Magazine, praised Mariarsquos efforts on the new podcast. He said: ldquoShe has been absolutely brilliant.ldquoThe first podcast was just me and her having a chat about our own experiences. We are  years apart so we have dferent experiences.To listen to the podcast, go to play.acast s this-ability-podcast

title: new-group-tackling-issues-river-esk
story: The Esk River Improvement Groupwas set up following concerns about mine water discharge, sewage, and discharge from combined sewage overflows.Its first meeting, held online last week, was hosted by local MSP Colin Beattie.The discussion was attended by key stakeholders such as the Scottish Environment Protection Agency , Scottish Water, the Coal Authority, East Lothian Council and community councillors, amongst other interested bodies.Mr Beattie said: ldquoThe issues with the River Esk have been ongoing for a long time and I know that my constituents are frustrated that no permanent solutions have been found.ldquoI wanted to establish a group where we look at the overall health of the River Esk and bring together those who are already working to make improvements to the quality of the water. It is much easier to see a result when we are all working collectively to resolve an issue and that is the exact purpose of this forum.ldquoIt is important to me that members of the community are involved and I am pleased we have many representatives from our community councils working with the group, and also some local establishments such as Newbattle Abbey College and Musselburgh Racecourse. It is heartening that so many people are willing to commit to volunteering their time to make active change on this matter.He added: ldquoI was pleased to discuss what progress was being made on these matters already, as well as thinking forward to establish what we need to do to stop these issues arising again in the future.ldquoAll constituents also have a part to play by ensuring they understand what not to flush down the toilet and by helping to educate others. Lessening the amount of sewage debris, which is often full of flushed wipes and sanitary towels, is an essential part in maintaining the cleanliness of the river.ldquoI am very pleased that the Coal Authority are putting in place a system to clean the mining discharge from Junkiersquos Adit, and also that Scottish Water, supported by SEPA, are actively working to undertake clean-ups on the Esk and improve their existing systems to prevent sewage spills going forward.ldquoI would like to remind my constituents that this group is not a substitute for reporting issues, and thatconstituents see pollution in the river then they should report this urgently to SEPA via their pollution reporting tool at www.sepa.org.uk EnvironmentalEvents or get in touch with Scottish Water directly, either through their website or by calling   .ldquoConstituents have a vital role to play by reporting problems when they see them, which allows them to be investigated more quickly and this will allow Scottish Water to undertake urgent clean-up.ldquoAnyone who would like to know more about the group is welcome to contact me at colin.beattie.msp@parliament.scot and I will gladly add them to ERIGrsquos mailing list.

title: nearly-50-m-co-stores-shut-haddington-musselburgh-survive
story: The company, which has been in Haddington for more than  years and in Musselburgh for more than , had appointed administrators in April as the coronavirus outbreak forced the closure of most UK retailers for nearly four months.Positively, Haddingtonrsquos Court Street store and Musselburghrsquos High Street branch have survived.Andy McGeoch, MCorsquos chief executive, said: ldquoIt quickly became clear that the best way to save most jobs and most stores was to enter administration, with a new company acquiring the assets of the old business, and this process has now been finalised.ldquoCovid has been by far the biggest challenge our family business has faced in almost  years, and I am really pleased that we have been able to maintain a presence in over  communitiesldquoCovid- means many people donrsquot feel comfortable travelling on public transport or visiting busy city centres and that can be good news for local High Street stores like MCo.ldquoThatrsquos why we are looking at ways of working in partnership with other local retailers to highlight the tremendous range of shopping that can be found in communities like this all over the country.The administration process, which is being managed by Deloitte, will see the number of MCo stores drop from  to .About  people are being made redundant from a total workforce of more than ,.The Musselburgh store has seven members of staff, with the Haddington branch employing  people neither store is affected by the restructuring.

title: plans-prestonpans-town-centre-revealed
story: The measures are being brought in by East Lothian Council under its Spaces for People scheme.It says that due to the limitations on space in the town, it is important that more spaces are introduced for people on foot, in wheelchairs and on bikes.A council spokesperson said: ldquoSupporting safe physical distancing for essential journeys and exercise is vitalwe are to suppress Covid-.ldquoIt will also improve opportunities for walking and cycling, creating environments that foster healthy and sustainable travel habits.Since last month, several new measures have already been introduced to Prestonpans, including a town-wide mph speed limit which also covers Cockenzie and Port Seton.Additional traffic calming measures were also brought in to allow the council to respond to requests for the use of public space, make it easier for people to cross the roadnecessary to maintain social distancing and support walking and cycling to school.Over the next few weeks, more measures will be introduced.On the south-east side of Prestonpans High Street, outside the Filling Station sandwich shop, the pavement will be widened and parking spaces for four cars removed the existing disabled parking space will remain.A three-metre-wide hard-surfaced temporary cycle route will be introduced adjacent to the north-western side of Edinburgh Road, between Prestonpans and Cockenzie.A temporary mph speed limit is also set to be introduced for Edinburgh Road, with regular traffic calming measures along the route.Measures to increase space for pedestrians on busy routes to school and at the school gates are being considered plans include widening pavements.More details on routes to school and the chance for members of the public to comment on them are available at bit.ly afajKcBefore the end of the year, the council hopes to explore the option of installing a public ebike hire station for eight bikes at Prestonpans Community Centre, Prestonpans High Street and in Cockenzie on Edinburgh Road and East Lorimer Place.Fiona OrsquoDonnell, ward councillor, said: ldquoI want to see businesses in our high streets able to operate safely.ldquoThese measures will help them do that with space for people to pass when queues are forming outside.ldquoFeeling they can shop and use other businesses safely will, I hope, encourage more people to use them, keep them open and protect jobs.ldquoThe mph limit will keep us all safer when out and about. I have already seen that it is making it easier for pedestrians to cross the road.ldquoI know it requires a change from drivers, and want to appeal to them to stick to the new limit.Brian Weddell, chair of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoIrsquom very supportive [of the plans], particularly the slowing of traffic as wersquove been campaigning with Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry Community Councils for a couple of years to get traffic speeds reduced entering the villages, so hopefully it will lead to that.He also expressed his support for the cycle path plans.

title: musselburgh-mcdonalds-plan-rejected-east-lothian-council
story: The fast food chain applied for planning permission to build the new restaurant, which would open  hours a day, next to the townrsquos Tesco store as it looked to draw customers from the supermarket into its drive-thru.However, claims by the chainrsquos representative Paula Reed-Smith that the number of visits to the restaurant from Musselburgh Grammar School, on the other side of the supermarket, would be lsquolimitedrsquo were disputed by local councillors.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee met virtually to discuss the plans for land to the east of Inveravon Terrace, off Olivebank Road, and questions were asked about why McDonaldrsquoswas looking to place a drive-thru in a town centre and near a secondary school.Ms Reed-Smith told the committee: ldquoWe anticipate pedestrian visits from the school will be limited.ldquoWe did not choose the location because of Musselburgh Grammar School, we chose it because of the location of Tesco.However, ward councillor Andy Forrest told the committee it would be a short walk to the restaurant for youngsters.He said: ldquoFrom the back door of the school to the front door of the new McDonaldrsquostakes a -second stroll.Councillor Stuart Currie, fellowMusselburgh ward member, who called in the application which was recommended for approval by planning officers, said children would ldquogravitate to the restaurant.He said: ldquoAbout  kids go to Tesco at lunchtime. We will have hundreds of kids walking through Tesco car park to McDonaldrsquos, they will gravitate to it.Musselburgh Area Partnership and Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council both objected to the plans, which drew  objections and two statements of support.Local resident Lynda Baird spoke in favour of the new restaurant, telling the committee that as a mother of four teenage children she welcomed it.She said: ldquoI worked for McDonaldrsquosand the food was always top quality the hygiene standards and training offered is also top quality.Ms Baird also hit back at social media ldquobullies who she claimed had attacked her and anyone who spoke out in favour of the drive-thru on Facebook.She told the committee: ldquoThere has been social bullying of people in support of McDonaldrsquos. I am badly dyslexic and was severely bullied by those against it.ldquoIf you donrsquot want it, donrsquot go, but donrsquot bully people who do want it.But Kirsten Leask, another local resident, urged the committee to reject the McDonaldrsquosapplication, pointing out that the health and wellbeing of children was at the heart of council policy.She said: ldquoThe proposed developmentrsquos location is within walking distance of not just Musselburgh Grammar School but three primary schools.Iain Clark, from the area partnership, also pointed out that three McDonaldrsquosrestaurants near Musselburgh were based out of town centres and away from schools, adding: ldquoWhy should Musselburgh be the exception Bernard Harkins, from the community council, pointed out thatMussselburgh town centre was an Air Quality Management zone because of pollution caused by traffic congestion pre-Covid- lockdown.He said: ldquoDuring lockdown we did see pollution levels fall, with the weekend of May  seeing zero levels recorded. We should be building on that.The councilrsquos roads department came under fire for ruling that traffic attracted by the drive-thru would not have a ldquosignicant impact on current congestion after using a peak hour model to measure it.Councillor Katie Mackie, Musselburgh ward member, said that she had recently timed a drive along theof the road which would be used by the drive-thru and it took her more than five minutes.She said: ldquoI have had more complaints from local residents about this application than any other issue since I was elected in .ldquoThere is no peak hour in Musselburgh town centre, congestion is round the clock.The planning committee voted to go against officersrsquo recommendation and refuse the application on the grounds of its impact on traffic, air quality and noise impact on the amenity of the surrounding residences.

title: scotlands-rail-fares-set-price-hike----much
story: Those travelling on the railway could be faced with a .% increase in season tickets from as early as January ndash however it is understood ministers are considering delaying the  rise due to low passenger numbers as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.The Scottish Government, as well as their UK and Welsh counterparts, regulate rises for around half of fares, including season tickets on most commuter routes, some off-peaktickets on long-distance journeys, and tickets for travel around major cities at any time.Despite the rise, Transport Scotland bosses say ScotRail fares are on average % cheaper than those across the rest of the UK.Examples of potential season ticket prices next year after a .% rise include:A Transport Scotland spokeswoman said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring that rail fares are affordable for passengers and taxpayers across Scotland.ldquoWe have taken action to keep fares down and ScotRail fare are still on average, % cheaper than those across the rest of the UK.ldquoWe are currently in the process of considering the options regarding future fares and tickets in relation to todayrsquos announcement on the July RPI figure as part of the wider rail recovery work post the Covid- pandemic.UK Government Department for Transport figures show car use has nearly ed to pre-pandemic levels, but rail travel is below a third of what it was before the crisis despite lockdown restrictions easing.All revenue and cost risks from train companies were transferred to the UK, Scottish and Welsh governments in March to avoid franchises collapsing.This has already cost taxpayers at least pound. billion.

title: petition-museum-flight-plans-signed-nearly-6-500
story: The new visitor centre for the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune was refused planning permission by East Lothian Council after it involved cutting down the trees in an ancient woodland to allow planes to be moved into it.National Museums Scotland has lodged an appeal over the rejection of its plans with Scottish Ministers.It said the tree removal was required to ldquodecant large fixed-wing aircraft from their current home to the new indoor exhibition centre, and saplings would be planted to replace the lost woodland.However, objectors argued that an alternative site could still be found and the need to protect the woodland far outweighed the need for the new centre.More than  written objections have been lodged with the Scottish Government Reporter as part of the appeal however, an online petition was rejected initially because it was said to be the wrong format.That decision has now been overruled by the Reporter, who has allowed the petition, which has , names on it, to be included in evidence.Alerting National Museums Scotland and East Lothian Council to the decision, case officer Laura Walker said: ldquoAn external link webpage was sent to myself back in June. The link openedup to a petition. I rejected this due to the format it was submitted .ldquoThe Reporter has now agreed that the petition can be acceptedsent in by a dferent format, which the organiser has done. The Reporter has confirmed an unaccompanied site visit will be carried out at the site proposed for the centre before a decision will be made over whether any additional information is required or a public hearing held.

title: east-lothian-council-peoples-energy-form-money-saving-partnership
story: East Lothian Energy will see the local authority work alongside Peoplersquos Energy to offer affordable, sustainable and fair energy for residents throughout the county as part of a joint commitment to eradicate fuel poverty.The new initiative sees Peoplersquos Energy, in association with the council, offering a special iable and fixed tarf that is discounted from its regular tarfs and available exclusively to East Lothian residents.The offer equates to potential savings of up to pound annually compared with the current energy price cap , based on Ofgemrsquos medium typical domestic consumption values energy usage.Councillor Norman Hampshire, council spokesman for the environment, described the scheme as ldquoquite a unique initiative.He said: ldquoEast Lothian Energy gives county residents the exclusive opportunity to purchase affordable, sustainable and fair energy. We hope this will be attractive to householders across a mix of tenures ndash including tenants and homeowners.ldquoAs well as saving money and helping to reduce fuel poverty, East Lothian Energy is a great way of enabling customers to support the environment and tackling climate change ndash a key priority for us as a council.ldquoThat is because all of the electricity comes from  per cent renewable sources.ldquoEast Lothian Energy customers will receive automatic Peoplersquos Energy membership ndash with  per cent of their profits being paid back to domestic members through an annual rebate.David Pike, CEO and co-founder of Peoplersquos Energy, based at Danderhall, said: ldquoWithin East Lothian, it is estimated that almost a quarter of householdsare living in fuel poverty, equating to , homes.ldquoWith this new affordable tarf for East Lothian residents, we have the potential to reduce the fuel poverty gap in the area quite considerably.ldquoPeoplersquos Energy is a social enterprise that puts people and the planet before profits.ldquoWersquore delighted to have the opportunity to partner with East Lothian Council to help make a positive change.To sign up, visit peoplesenergy eastlothian

title: coronavirus-scotland-face-coverings-become-law-schools-workplaces
story: Nicola Sturgeon told her coronavirus briefing yesterday that it was ldquounder review, as the Scottish Government attempt to strike the right balance between ldquobeing as normal as possible and the learning experience for young people.It comes after a number of confirmed COVID- cases were reported in pupils across the country ndash with classes and even whole schools having to self-isolate.Face coverings could become mandatory in secondary schoolsA public health expert has since said that the mandatory wearing of masks in workplaces and secondary schools should be considered to keep them open.Coverings are compulsory in many indoor settings including shops, on public transport and in places such as cinemas, galleries, museums, libraries and banks.Professor Linda Bauld said they could be considered in other settingslevels of coronavirus go up.What did she say Asked in an interview on BBC Radio Scotland whether introducing face coverings in workplaces should be considered to allow more people to get back to work, she said: ldquoI donrsquot think we should rule it out."I thinkcases go up and we need particular settings to reopen that canrsquot, for whatever reason, face coverings indoors absolutely, but at the moment those sectors that can work from home ndash thatrsquos the message that I agree with ndash should continue to do that.Prof Bauld, who is professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh, said the virus is at a ldquovery low level in terms of where we are in Scotland and that while it is circulating it is localised in terms of the rise in cases.Face coverings are already mandatory in some situationsShe said the best way to protect schools is to keep virus levels low, but that face coverings could be considered for secondary school pupils to avoid having to pause education.Prof Bauld said: ldquoIn terms of the cases that wersquore hearing about in school pupils, these are not cases that are occurring because pupils are catching the virus in the school setting, they are cases that are arising in the community, and when we have the virus circulating in the community even at low levels we know that children and young people may get it and then thereforethey go into the school they are still carrying it.She added: ldquoI thinkwe wanted to talk about, for example, face coverings for secondary school pupils rather than closing a school, thatrsquos another step we might want to discuss, thatrsquos being discussed in other places, but we donrsquot need it at the moment."We just have to think about what are the alternatives to having to pause education again because wersquore all trying to avoid that.Itrsquos now mandatory to wear a face covering in more indoor public places in Scotland.This video explains where you must wear one #Detailed guidance # https:t.co QmCaYPog pic YWJXeeHWhat did the First Minister say During her daily briefing yesterday, the First Minister addressed the concerns over cases in pupils ndash as well as responding to images of crowded hallways and playgrounds.Ms Sturgeon said the introduction of face masks in schools would not be ruled out.She said: "When we see anything like that, directors of education in relevant councils will be contacted to make sure they are applying all of the right guidance."We will keep all of this under review, and that includes title: muirfield-host-womens-open-first-time-2022
story: The world-famous course, which has held the menrsquos event  times, has been confirmed as the venue for the prestigious competition in .A decision to allow female members at Muirfield for the first time by the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers was taken in . Previously, women had only been allowed to play the course as guests or visitors.A vote the previous year had seen a vote to scrap the clubs men-only policy fall narrowly short of the required two-thirds majority.Following that vote, the venue was removed from organisers The RAs rota for hosting The Open ndash it was reinstated following the  reversal of the men-only policy.Martin Slumbers, chief executive of The RA, was delighted with Muirfield receiving the  Womens Open, a decision which was announced on the eve of this yearrsquos event, which is being played at Royal Troon.Next year, Carnoustie will host the competition, which was won last year by Hinako Shibuno, with Muirfield then welcoming players in .Walton Heath , St Andrewsand Royal Porthcawlwere also announced as future venues.Mr Slumbers said: ldquoWith our partners at AIG, we have a real ambition to grow and elevate the AIG Womens Open for the benefit of the worlds leading golfers and so we are excited to confirm our intention to play the next five championships at these renowned courses.ldquoIt has truly been a collaborative effort from all the venues involved to make this schedule possible and the flexibility that they have shown in adjusting their own calendars has been vital in allowing us to confirm our plans for the championship through to .ldquoWe are grateful for their support, particularly during a time when golf has been impacted by the ongoing pandemic, and we look forward to working with these venues to deliver an outstanding experience to be enjoyed by everyone involved in the AIG Womenrsquos Open.North Berwicks Catriona Matthew won the tournament in , when it was hosted at Royal Lytham and St Annes.Muirfield, Walton Heath and Royal Porthcawl will all be hosting the womenrsquos major championship for the first time.Muirfield, near Gullane, has a prestigious history of hosting Major championships, having last held The Open in .Phil Mickelson lted the Claret Jug on that occasion and the course also hosted The Curtis Cup in  and , as well as the Vagliano Trophy in  and .Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who lives in nearby Gullane, described it as ldquogreat news for the club and great news for East Lothian.He said: ldquoThis part of East Lothian is not known as Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast for nothing.ldquoIt is the greatest stretch of golf courses in the whole of Scotland,not the whole of the UK, and Muirfield is the jewel in the crown that continues to attract visitors from all over the world, who want to play Muirfield, Gullane, North Berwick and Dunbar.ldquoWe saw the Ladies Scottish Open event [at The Renaissance Club, near Dirleton, last week] being held without spectators.ldquoIt is great to have it here but not having spectators is a great shame because that adds to the whole atmosphere and the draw.ldquoHopefully, in two yearsrsquo time, we have a vaccine [for Covid-] and we are back to as close to normal as possible.

title: storm-ellen-high-winds-expected-east-lothian
story: Although the storm is expected to be worst in the west, East Lothian and other parts of south-east Scotland are also due to be impacted.The Met Office has issued a yellow be aware warning of wind for East Lothian covering the period from am to pm tomorrow.The Met Office says that strong winds on Friday are expected to lead to some travel disruption and could possibly disrupt power as well.It says that some travel delays are likely, while some short term loss of power and other services is also possible."Itrsquos likely that some coastal routes, sea fronts and coastal communities are affected by spray and or large waves," the Met Office adds, as well as "some damage to trees, with debris on roads possible given the time of year".Although the storm is not predicted to be as severe as some of those in the early part of the year, the unseasonal nature of a storm of this type striking in summer is expected to bring its own problems, as trees are in full leaf and therefore could suffer more damage than usual.

title: nina-young-walking-north-coast-500-teapot-trust-memory-sister-verity
story: Nina Young has laced up her walking boots and aims to complete the picturesque North Coast  in aid of the Teapot Trust.The charity was founded by her mum and dad, Laura and John, nearly  years ago after the death of their daughter Verity.The eight-year-old spent much of her short le in hospital coping with illness and managing the effects of her treatment, first for lupus and then for cancer.Art gave Verity a way of expressing herself and was an essential coping strategy for the whole family, so John and Laura wanted to help other children and families who were struggling.Nina, who has been joined by friends and university coursemates during her fundraiser, said: ldquoAs a medical student, I really see how mental health takes a knock when you have physical health conditions to live with, every day of your le, constantly on medication or injections.ldquoThe Teapot Trustrsquos art therapy sessions really build great coping strategies for kids and so I am delighted that the money I am raising is going towards that.Nina left her home in Gullane at the end of last month to head to the starting point of Inverness.From there, she has headed north, covering an average of  mileseach day.She spoke to the Courier while walking between Melvich and Strathy, on Scotlandrsquos north coast, last Tuesday morning.The -year-old said: ldquoWith people doing lots of challenges during lockdown and raising money for charity, I thought: lsquoIf they can do it, why canrsquot I rsquoldquoMy flatmate and I had planned to drive the North Coast  before lockdown and that did not happen.ldquoMy sister Isla, she loves the song Irsquom Gonna Beby The Proclaimers and I was thinking what I could do for the Teapot Trust.ldquoIt is a small charity and struggling for funds with the pandemic.The former Gullane Primary School and Loretto School pupil set off from Inverness on July .However, not everything has been straightforward along the way.She said: ldquoOn day three, we were coming down a hill and my knee twisted.ldquoI thought that was it.ldquoI made it to the next campsite and the next day I could not finish the walk.ldquoA friend had come up to help take our bags for a day and he gave me a lt and my friend finished the day off.ldquoI was worried it was all over but wersquove survived with ice, ibuprofen and a knee brace.ldquoIt has got better, especially as you get the distance and you are making progress.Originally, Nina set a fundraising target of pound, before she set off for the Highlands.Already, that target has been smashed, with the University of Edinburgh student hoping to complete the route by the end of the month.She said: ldquoIt seemed like a lot of money.ldquoWe have broken it already, which is pretty cool.ldquoWe have been amazed by the kindness of people donating and it is a great motivation.ldquoI get an email every time someone donates and you get a little lsquopingrsquo on your phone.ldquoIt is worth the sore feet and hopefully it keeps coming in.The Teapot Trust, which is based in Musselburgh, has helped more than , children and young people in Scotland since its launch, giving them art therapy sessions.Nina said of her late sister: ldquoVerity was so bubbly. I was quite young as well ndash I was nine years old when she died.ldquoEverything was fine and OK in some ways because I was young and sheltered from the stress of the hospital.To support the good cause, go to www.teapot-trust.org fundraisers we-will-walk--miles

title: phone-box-removal-35-list-40-east-lothian-taken-away
story: East Lothian Council gave the green light for the removal of  phone boxes across the county, with just two kept in use and three adopted for alternative use after a public consultation.Last week, vans were sent out to take away the last nine of the boxes marked for removal.BT said it had consulted with the local authority and communities over retaining the phone boxes before taking any action.A spokesperson said: ldquoMost people now have a mobile phone and calls made from our public telephones have fallen by around  per cent in the past decade.ldquoWe consider a number of factors before consulting on the removal of payphones, including whether others are available nearby and usage.ldquoWe consulted with East Lothian Council on the removal of  payphones and provided communities with the chance to comment on our proposals.ldquoIf the council tell us they want a payphone to remain, we will keep it.ldquoAs part of the consultation, we also offered communities the chance to adopt traditional red heritage phone boxes for just pound through our Adopt a Kiosk scheme.ldquoThe need for payphones in emergencies is also reducing as  per cent of the UK has either G or G coverage. As long as therersquos network coverage from at least one network, itrsquos possible to call , even when therersquos no credit or no coverage from your own mobile provider.Out of  phone boxes earmarked for removal, the local authority indicated only two were to remain active: Eskside West, Musselburgh and Bayswell Road, Dunbar.Three were adopted by community groups in West Saltoun, Dirleton and Bolton.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoAny decision on whether to remove a phone boxis for BT to make.ldquoAs part of its process, BT noties the local community and the council of any proposal intention to remove a phone box.ldquoThe councilrsquos role is to feed back any comments to BT from the local community.ldquoPhone boxes can be lsquoadoptedrsquo by local community or charity organisations.The consultation for the latest removals was launched last year.BT said only nine working phone boxesin East Lothian had not been put forward for public consultation over their future.In , there were an estimated  working phone kiosks in the county.Some phone boxes in the county have become iconic.In East Linton, the phone box on Drylaw Street was removed however, the one on the villagersquos High Street, which has category-B listed building status, was not on the list.It is a well-known tourist attraction which dates back to  and is often photographed by visitors.Judith Priest, from Dunpender Community Council, said attempts had been made to adopt the High Street box, without success.She said: ldquoItrsquos a sorry sight and we would like to adopt it.ldquoItrsquos a popular box and visitors from abroad take their photos with it but it hasnrsquot been painted in years.

title: gateside-retail-park-work-starts-site-haddington
story: Diggers and heavy machinery arrived at Gateside, on Haddingtonrsquos western edge, last week.Plans for a retail park, made up of five units, were given the green light by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee shortly before Christmas last year.However, work on the site has been slow due to the coronavirus pandemic and related restrictions.When complete, the development, which was submitted by EPICLtd, will include three major retail stores, two restaurants ndash with one including a drive-thru ndash and nearly  parking spaces.Aldi, Home Bargains and The Food Warehouse are all expected to move into the site as the retail stores, alongside Greggs and Costa as the restaurants.A new petrol station is also planned for the site, which is sandwiched between the A and B.When the proposals were revealed, it was suggested that  jobs would be created at the retail park, with a further  construction jobs during the building process.

title: tims-tales-save-wood-national-museum-flight-plans
story: But National Museums Scotland has appealed and it has now gone to the Scottish Government Reporter for a final decision.Before my recent walk in the wood, I had only admired the trees from the vantage point of the museum on our visits there. Itrsquos not so easy to access, but the fact the trees are now under threat made me want to discover the place before it might be too late. As I write, the decision has yet to be made on the fate of the trees.Irsquom a lover of history and totally understand the need to create a safe, weather-proof home for these historic planes, and to keep the museum as much an authentic visiting experience as possible. But there is a huge amount of space in the existing museum area, so the destruction of woodland seems unnecessary.The museum argues that any additional modern structures near the runway will undermine the historic look of the airfield. The proposed new visitor centre will, they say, create much-needed new jobs. So cutting down the trees to move the planes and create a new home for them is, the museum authorities argue, the only realistic option for them. They say that refusal of their plans will put the new jobs at risk.I totally understand the need for jobs at this time in particular, but the trouble is the approach taken by the museum is part of the reason the world is facing an ecological crisis with deforestation, the destruction of habitats and the extinction of wildle. It is part of the mindset that sees nature as ldquoin the way of development.Donrsquot be ridiculously dramatic, I hear some folks say this is not the Amazon or a rainforest in Indonesia, itrsquos a small wood in East Lothian.And that is precisely the point. It is a small but very rare example of a wood with mature trees in our county. It is a special place, with a ersity of trees and buzzing with wildle. Walk under its canopy and you will discover that. I know itrsquos proposed to plant new trees in a dferent area as compensation, but this wonrsquot connect to the wood and will take generations to grow. It will never replace what will be lost.If we seriously want to do something about the ecological disaster we are making on our planet then we need to start in our own backyard. We canrsquot campaign against deforestation, habitat destruction and declare a climate emergency, and then say: ldquoWell, the rules donrsquot apply to us when we want to destroy woodland to move some planes.Deforestation has a multitude of justications all over the world: dam building, road construction, cattle ranching, extreme poverty of subsistence farmers, profit from timber, oil exploration and pipelines, mining: the list is long. The point is there will always be someone with an economic justication for environmental destruction.While it may be on a much smaller scale, the proposal to destroy irreplaceable woodland in order to move some planes is a product of the same mindset that has brought us to a point of environmental and climate crisis.This mindset is revealed in the Historic Environment Scotland response to the proposal. This is the public body charged with protecting Scotlandrsquos built heritage. It has said: ldquoWe would not consider the trees of Sunnyside Strip to be directly related to the cultural signicance of the scheduled monument ndash they are visible but do not relate to our understanding of the monument as a wartime airfield.In other words, woodland isnrsquot part of our heritage mature trees, many of which were around before the war, arenrsquot historic or worthy of value in themselves. Really The wood is far more a historic part of the wartime airfield site than the massive car park. It seems to be a very selective viewpoint.The truth is that the UK is one of the most nature-depleted countries on the planet. A quarter of our already-decimated wild mammals are in danger of extinction. Our woodlands are small and dispersed, but all the more vital for the habitat they provide. East Lothian has huge developmental pressure, and this wood is a rare and vital part of naturersquos increasingly precarious foothold in our county.A changed mindset would be one which makes the protection of nature and the environment the initial default position. Developers should then take this priority as the starting point for proposals.That hasnrsquot happened with this plan, and credit to the council for rejecting it.There has been so much publicity and justied outrage recently over the destruction and littering of our land by people lsquowildrsquo camping and disrespecting nature. So many people, it seems, just donrsquot care, or seem unable to appreciate the gt of our natural environment and its importance.There is a disconnect from nature at the heart of this. We will never solve the environmental and climate crisis we are in until we can foster love and appreciation of nature, of which we are a part. Our childrenrsquos future literally depends on this.And institutions such as National Museums Scotland should be part of the solution, not the problem. Instead of viewing the woodland as irrelevant to the visitor experience, it could be used to enhance it. The wood is a magic place, with younger trees growing amidst towering old mature ones.My kids were in wonder as they explored the wood, peering up at the tops of the trees, and an old oak caught their attention as its boughs seemed to dip asto say hello. We spent a wonderful hour being immersed in nature.Many of our children, in fact many adults, have limited opportunities to explore and enjoy such places. Imagine the extra possibility of a nature walk in the tall wood, where wildle thrives and trees older than the airfield can tell their story. This wood is not an intrusion for the visitor but a potential wonderful addition. Get the ranger service to do talks and tours about this amazing place, a treasure hunt use it to enhance peoplersquos connection to nature ndash an extra experience.Woodland is not just a habitat for wildle, itrsquos a habitat for us humans too. Enjoying nature and learning about its importance should not be seen as a contradiction to enjoying historic planes.While Irsquom aware that itrsquos only part of the wood under threat, the proposal to destroy a large section of it will result in a tragic loss of trees and the habitat they provide. But itrsquos not just the destruction in itself, itrsquos also the precedent and example it sets for future developments.I really hope the Reporter will uphold the councilrsquos decision, and the museum, which is a fantastic and well-loved historic place to visit, will consider a new location for the visitor centre. Then we will all be winners.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-august-18-20-1995-1970-1920
story: lsquoENOUGH is enoughrsquo was the message from traders in North Berwick, reported the East Lothian Courier on August , .The opening of North Berwickrsquos sixth charity shop this week has sparked controversy ndash and fears have been raised that a seventh could be on the cards.Traders claimed the resort had now reached ldquosaturation point with fundraising outlets, which are now selling new goods in addition to second-hand items.They said the charities were setting up shop on prime sites, and argued that they were ldquosubsidising them through having to pay higher rates.Fears that the trend could ultimately lead to a downturn in the local economy and the death of the High Street as a shopping centre were also expressed.The row follows the opening of the Chest, Heart  Stroke Associationrsquos outlet at a former delicatessen shop in the High Street on Monday.A RE-ENACTMENT of the Battle of Dunbar was postponed as it clashed with a model power boat demonstration, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .The re-enactment of the Battle of Dunbar, which is to be staged by the Royal Scots as part of their recruiting drive in East Lothian, has been postponed for a week because it would have clashed with the running of a model power boat demonstration to be held on Sunday, September . It will now take place on September .The Royal Scots will be spending a weekend in Dunbar and will be holding a dance in the Victoria Ballroom for the youngsters.MEANWHILE, there was avisit from Australia.A Haddington man who joined the Australian Army almost  years ago is at present revisiting the town on a short holiday. He is Sgt. Alex. Sutherland, son of Mrs J. Sutherland and the late Mr Sutherland, of  Orchard Grove. Alex, who was a painter in Haddington, went to Sydney for training after signing up in London.lsquoATTEMPTED rescue of a prisonerrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .A young man named Alexander Broadfoot, residing at the Coalfauld, West Harbour, Cockenzie, appeared before Bailie Robertson at Edinburgh City Police Court on Monday, charged with committing a breach of the peace on Saturday, and assaulting two constables of the Edinburgh City Police. title: zans-wildlife-diary-otter-esk
story: Although I love ying the subjects of my photographs and learning about new species as I travel across Scotland, my favourite animal remains the kingfisher at the River Esk at Musselburgh.Very often, when I go on a walk along the river, I chat with other wildle enthusiasts. This is how I heard about an otter at the Esk for the first time three years ago.A few people mentioned they had seen this elusive creature a few years ago, but never since.The otter became my new photography challenge. I tried visiting the river at dferent times of the day, especially at dawn and dusk, when otters are more active, always trying to keep the noise down to a minimum.After two years of searching, my hope was gone and I almost gave up. Until one sunny day in April during lockdownhellipThe weather that day was enjoyable, so Chris and I decided to go on a walk. The local path was very busy the dog walkers, cyclists, families with children and joggers were enjoying the sun whilst social distancing.As always, I kept my eyes low on the water hoping to see the kingfisher.As we followed the river upstream to the area at The Grove, I spotted something moving in the water.I grabbed Chrisrsquo hand and I pulled him down on the ground right behind a bush.It was not a kingfisher but something I did not expect to see in the middle of the day... an otter fishing!We managed to crawl down the slope and lie down so we would not disturbit.Whilst I was photographing the otter, I also heard a cheery pee-pee-pee and saw the kingfisher flying past the otter. What a day!Since then I have seen the otter a couple more times.The Eurasian otter is a secretive, semi-aquatic species with chocolate brown fur, webbed feet, and a powerful tail. Their thick coats are built of two layers of fur: an inner layer that works as insulation, and the outer, waterproof layer. The two-layered system prevents their skin from direct contact with water and subsequent temperature loss.Their nostrils and ears stay closed as otters swim underwater.Despite being excellent swimmers, they cannot hold their breath underwater for long periods the average time underwater is about  seconds as they e.Otters are solitary, territorial animals, that live in underground holes called lsquoholtsrsquo. The size of their territory ies and depends on the quality of the habitat, amount of food and number of possible holts.It is also known that a male otter has a larger territory that can even overlap several female ottersrsquo territories. Otters usually have a well-defined area within their grounds in which they feed, rest and breed.Seeing signs of otters is generally easier than seeing the animals themselves. If you happen to find yourself at the riverbank or a sea loch, look for five-toed footprints and otter droppings , that are left in places such as fallen trees, rocks and weirs.Spraints are easily identiable as they contain visible fish bones and have a characteristic and not particularly unpleasant smell that has been described as ranging from fish to freshly brewed jasmine tea!The otter that you may see at the coast is very often called a lsquosea otterrsquo however, this is the same species as the animals that live further inland.If you would like to share how you get on finding the otters oryou have any rare kind of wildle in your area, I would love to hear from you.Speak to you next month!zanslensfacebook zanslens instagram zans_lens twitter zans_lens

title: tantallon-castle-john-muir-birthplace-among-attractions-reopening
story: Historic Environment Scotlandhas confirmed that Tantallon Castle, east of North Berwick, will accept visitors with pre-booked tickets from next Friday .A phased reopening of some HES sites title: retired-musselburgh-nurse-writes-book-caring-people-dementia
story: Dee Jenkins, , of Eskmills Road, said the main aim of the publication ndash I Remember Dementia ndash was to encourage carers of dementia patients.Born in Dublin in , Mrs Jenkins, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, came to Scotland in  to enter a religious order, the Novitiate for the Sisters of La Sagesse, at Leuchie House, North Berwick. When it closed as a convent, the home became available for respite work for multiple sclerosis sufferers.Mrs Jenkins went on to train at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh from  to . She then joined the initial team of nurses at St Columbarsquos Hospice when it opened in .Mrs Jenkins left the order after  years and moved to Wales in  to take up a position as matron in a care home specialising in dementia care.She continued to care for people with dementia after ing to Scotland in , spending a decade in Edinburgh until she retired at the age of .Mrs Jenkins said: ldquoI worked in independent care homes as a manager, with the responsibility of training staff in this specialised field.ldquoI was inspired to write the book because people are becoming more aware of dementia and conscious of the dficulties it involves.ldquoI hope that my experiences might encourage those caring at home and provide some practical help and guidance.She added: ldquoIrsquom aware that Musselburgh as a town has shown a consciousness and willingness to provide supportive groups in this field of care, and hope this book may be of additional help and interest.The book is available on Amazon.

title: emergency-recess-procedures-east-lothian-council-ending
story: For the past five months, all decision-making powers were delegated to Monica Patterson, chief executive of the local authority, and the leaders of each of the three political parties ndash Councillor Willie Innes or Norman Hampshire , previously Jane Henderson and now Lachlan Bruce , and Stuart Curriendash during Covid- emergency recess procedures.The decision to invoke those procedures was made at the council meeting on St Patrickrsquos Day, March , ahead of lockdown being brought in.That will now end, with a view to ing to full council meetings.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoIt is anticipated that the first meeting of the council on August  and, subject to consideration of a related report at that meeting, all other public meetings until further notice, will operate on a virtual basis accessible to the public.

title: new-knox-academy-s1-pupils-welcomed-special-cake
story: Reigning Scottish School Cook of the Year ndash and Knox Academyrsquos very own cook ndash Maria Millar conjured up some brilliant baking ahead of youngsters finishing their summer holidays.The cake, a school shirt complete with school tie and Knox Academyrsquos crest, came with the message: lsquoWelcome st year .rsquoMaria baked the cake for pupils heading to school last Thursday, with S pupils, including her son Andrew, invited to come and try a piece.She wanted to create a tasty masterpiece, as P pupils never got the chance to have the traditional leaving event when moving from primary school to secondary school due to the coronavirus pandemic.She added: ldquoI wanted to give something to welcome the S pupils.The vanilla sponge, with strawberry jam, went down well with the pupils and staff.Maria said: ldquoPeople were saying they could not believe I made it but I wanted to do something for Knox.The hundreds of pupils heading to the Haddington secondary school can expect gastronomic delights.Maria, who is originally from Venezuela, picked up the national honour last year for the second time.Her menu of turkey meatballs in a red sauce served with rice primavera, followed by tres leche ndash three milk ndash cake, which includes condensed milk, evaporated milk and double cream, impressed judges and saw her regain the title she won in .Sue Cook, headteacher at the school, thanked Maria.She said: ldquoIt was so lovely of Maria to make this welcome cake.ldquoAll our Ss were offered a piece at lunchtime, with most taking it home for later .ldquoNot only was the design bespoke, featuring our Knox Academy school unorm, but it was mouth-wateringly good, too.

title: firth-forth-lobster-hatchery-features-bbc-show-great-food-guys
story: Chef Nick Nairn, who runs four restaurants, two cookery schools and has one Michelin star, and presenter Dougie Vipond, of Landward and Sportscene, visited the Firth of Forth Lobster Hatchery, based at North Berwick Harbour, as part of the second series of their TV show The Great Food Guys.The lobster hatchery rears juvenile lobsters from the larvae hatched from local female lobster stock. It then nurtures the juveniles through their most vulnerable stages until they can be released into the sea.Although it was forced to delay its summer opening due to lockdown, the hatcheryrsquos education container was reopened in July.The hatcheryrsquos production container, however, has remained closed to the public as Covid- meant it was unable to perform its usual duties.As well as reporting from the lobster hatchery, Dougie and Nick visited the town in the Landward van for the show, tempting local residents with some of their dishes.This marks the second time East Lothian has appeared in the show, with Phantassie Food near East Linton and some North Berwick residents featuring in the showrsquos first episode in July.This latest episode, the seventh in an eight-part series, is shown this evening at pm on the BBC Scotland channel and on Saturday at .am on BBC One.The series was filmed last year, before lockdown.

title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-left-bus-stop-gullane
story: North Berwick High Schoolrsquos parent council chairman took to social media to highlight concerns about incidents which had occurred,as youngsters from outwith the seaside town tried to use public services to get to class.Niall Bradley said he had been made aware of problems, ranging from bus timetables not matching new starting and going home times introduced, to buses not turning up, overcrowding and children being ldquoleft behind.His comments came after some parents vented their anger after pupils in Gullane were left at a bus stop on Monday morning, and were then told their normal service route had changed.East Coast Buses said it had been working with East Lothian Council to ensure there was enough provision for pupils and would continue to do so.And it said the issues had been caused by a ersion which was in place preventing its  service going to Gullane which has now been resolved.Mr Bradley took to social media to address the issue, saying: ldquoIrsquom aware of a list of concerns about buses: timings, buses not shaking up, overcrowding, children being left behind, failure to wearface coverings.ldquoI know some parents have written to the school, which is great, but Irsquove written to our ward councillors to make sure that they are aware of the issues and to ask them to take this up with Transport Services at East Lothian Council.One mum claimed pupils were again left stranded this morning in Gullane and others accused buses of failing to stop for pupils on the route, a claim denied by East Coast Buses.Another parent claimed some bus drivers were refusing to allow pupils to stand on the buses, while others were happy for them to crowd in, with claims some buses had children ldquostanding, sitting in the luggage racks and sitting on the stairs.The bus company said it had worked with the council to ensure capacity after months of a reduced service due to Covid-.A spokesperson said: ldquoIn advance of the schools reopening, we worked closely with East Lothian Council to add extra capacity to our network for children travelling to and from school.ldquoOn Monday, the first full day back for all school pupils, we encountered some minor issues predominately caused by a road closure and subsequent route ersions.ldquoAs a result not all pupils could be uplted as planned however, we have made a number of changes to increase overall capacity, including a timing change from Monday on the Service X to provide additional seats between Gullane and North Berwick at the time when children are travelling to school.ldquoAs we move forward, we will continue to liaise with East Lothian Council and local schools to continually review and introduce further changesand where required.North Berwick High School took to Twitter yesterday eveningto insist there was enough space on the bus servicestudents used the ldquoright ones.The school published its bus timetable with the comment: ldquoTransport have worked hard to resolve the issue with buses along the coastal routes.ldquoWe have plenty of capacity, provided pupils take the right buses to and from school, according to the timetable.An East Lothian Council spokesperson: ldquoThe  was not operating through Gullane due to roadworks in neighbouring West Fenton."Pupils in that area had separate transport arranged and our Transport Services team also arranged an additional  seater bus to service Gullane to compensate for the loss of service through Gullane. This was used by one pupil on its two days in operation.ldquoAs East Coast Buses is a public transport service, pupils are allowed to stand during transport. We also agree that face coverings should be worn as a mandatory requirement and are working with our schools and school communities to raise awareness of this national guidance."We are also working closely with North Berwick High School to align bus service timings with the schoolrsquos move to a common school day.ldquoHaving reviewed pupil numbers and available capacity on our buses we believe that there is sufficient capacity and the issues that are highlighting, notwithstanding the , are being exacerbated as most pupils have tried to access the very first bus to arrive."This was also highlighted when our own officer visited the village on Tuesday to better understand the issue. Again, we are working with our schools and transport providers to manage this process and would appreciate parental support. We would encourage pupils to make use of all buses serving the route.

title: giant-crane-vessel-helping-build-neart-na-gaoithe-windfarm
story: Neart na Gaoithewindfarm, which will feature  turbines, is being built  kilometres off the coast of Dunbar.The first phase of construction is getting under way, with a semi-submersible crane vessel, the Saipem S , now in place to start the installation of casings for piles.The S will also work on preparing the seabed in advance of the arrival of the steel foundation jackets on which the  wind turbine generators and two offshore substations will be installed.This giant vessel is nearly  metres long and is designed to be able to work in the most challenging weather conditions.It can carry out heavy lt operations up to , tonnes at sea.Full commissioning of the pound billion windfarm, which will also be visible from North Berwick and is owned by EDF Renewables and ESB, is due to be complete in .Matthias Haag, NnG project director, said: ldquoThe construction phase of the NnG offshore windfarm is now well under way and many people will be able to see the S starting construction work offshore.ldquoIt will be visible from much of the East Neuk of Fe and from North Berwick and Dunbar.ldquoWe have carefully considered the implications of Covid- and Scottish Government guidelines as the work gets under way offshore and for the continuing onshore works.Onshore work continues on the project at ious locations along the cable route, which starts at Thorntonloch beach and finishes in the Lammermuir Hills.

title: hard-work-bringing-dunbar-corn-exchange-back-use-remarkable
story: Dunbarrsquos Christmas lights team has been based in the townrsquos Corn Exchange, off High Street, for a number of years. However, concerns have regularly been raised about the condition of the building, which dates back to .Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, thanked volunteers for the hard work that had gone into ensuring the building did not become further dilapidated.She said: ldquoI was really thrilled to be invited to come and have a look at the Corn Exchange.ldquoIt is remarkable what the team has done there. It was damp, smelly and inhospitable and now it is fully lit, it is dry and it is comfortable.ldquoI think a huge thanks has to go to Graham Adams, Craig Rapson and the Christmas lights team for what they have done.

title: aldi-plans-reverse-vending-machines-north-berwick-tranent-stores
story: The lsquoreverse vending machinersquo would be in the car parks at the retailerrsquos North Berwick and Tranent stores.Plans for the machines are with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A statement included within the planning applications explained the purpose of the devices.It reads: ldquoA reverse vending machine , in its simplest form, is a device that accepts empty beverage containers and s a rewardto the user.ldquoThe user inserts the empty beverage container into the RVM, where it is scanned, identied and determined to be an eligible container.The statement continues: ldquoWhen consumers go into a shop or hospitality business to buy a drink, they will pay a small depositon top of the retail price.ldquoConsumers get their deposit back when theytheir empty plastic bottle, glass bottle or steel aluminium can.ldquoThere are two ways totheir empty containers. These can be ed manually over the counter or by using an automated reverse vending machine that scans the container barcode when they are deposited.If approved, the machines would result in the loss of five parking spaces outside the Tranent store, on Haddington Road, and four spaces at the store on North Berwickrsquos Dunbar Road.Plans for the North Berwick store were discussed at a local community council meeting on August .The community council welcomed the recycling containers but said it would be bestit was open at the same time as the store and restricted to those hours rather than open  hours.Member Peter Hamilton raised concerns neighbours had over potential noise, especiallypeople were putting bottles into the machine late at night.Further planning applications are expected for the supermarket chainrsquos other two county stores in Haddington and Musselburgh.A spokesperson for Aldi said: ldquoAldi is working to prepare for the introduction of the Deposit Return Schemein Scotland in line with the Governmentrsquos introduction date.ldquoThis includes reviewing the physical layout of stores to ensure they meet the requirements of the regulations covering DRS, including the installation of RVM in appropriate areas.

title: enjoyleisures-six-sports-centres-east-lothian-reopen-september
story: enjoyleisure, which,operates six sports centres in East Lothian on behalf of East Lothian Council,announced this evening that its centres would reopen on Monday, September .Meanwhile, FES Ltd, which operates the Mercait Gait Centre in Prestonpans, has also announced the centres intention to reopen on September , "subject to change in the event of new Government advice".In a statement, enjoyleisure said: "Whilst we welcome todayrsquos statement from the First Minister, enjoyleisure is committed to reopening its sport, leisure centres and swimming pools in East Lothian from Monday, September , which was the indicative date provided by Scottish Government three weeks ago."The safety of our customers and colleagues is our number one priority. We will not make any compromises on this."Our sports centres are multaceted buildings. As such, the magnitude and complexity that is required to prepare our sports centres for reopening in line with the Scottish Government and each official sporting bodyrsquos guidance cannot be underestimated."We have however, already made signicant progress in preparing our centres for reopening by making changes to the way we deliver our services to protect the communities of East Lothian."A number of social distancing and hygiene measures will be introduced at all centres, which include increased spacing between gym equipment, distinguishing entry and exiting points, and hand sanitiser stations. Signicantly increased cleaning regimes by staff will be implemented throughout the day to safeguard our customers and employees."The layouts of the gyms have been changed to enable customers to use the equipment at a safe distance from others. There will be a limit to the number of people allowed in the gym at any one time, along with a fixed -minute session time. As always, gym users should wipe down the equipment before and after they have used it, with the products provided."All swimming pools will consist of wider lanes and group tanks, with maximum numbers in place and a fixed swim session of  minutes plus  minutes for changing. Swimmers must follow the lanersquos one-way system."They will be able to change in the changing rooms before they swim however, we request that they arrive lsquoswim readyrsquo with costumes on under their clothes to speed up the changing process and get in the pool quicker."The capacity of fitness classes will be reduced to ensure people can space out from each other while exercising. All the equipment and the exercise area will be cleaned between classes."As a precaution, dry side changing rooms have been taken out of action and customers will be required to arrive dressed ready for their training session. Customer toilets, however, will be available."Mostof our childrenrsquos coached activity programmes will be resuming too. Childrenrsquos swimming lessons will restart from Monday, September , and classes within our gymnastics programme will resume from Monday, September . Previous participants will be contacted directly about the resumption and rebooking of lessons."Additionally, our sports halls will be available for racket sports and we will be welcoming back some of the local sports clubs who hire our facilities on a weekly basis. Please check with your club for start dates times."All activities will need to be pre-booked in advance. We have been developing our online booking system, and a number of sessional activities will be available to book online. We are also adding a waiting listfor fitness classes and gym sessions."Alongside the booking of activities, we will be asking all customers and visitors to provide us with their name and contact details in support of the NHS Test and Protect scheme."All direct debit paying members will be contacted regarding the reopening of facilities and provided with details on the new booking and operational procedures in place. We will also advise them of the options available regarding their membership payments."We regret that not all facilities will be opening immediately. This includes the health suites , soft play areas and squash courts . Additionally, the cafe facilities will remain temporarily closed, although vending machines will be available."In the coming weeks, all of our centre colleagues will complete a comprehensive training induction on the new safety measures and cleaning regimes we are putting in place. In addition, they will be updated on the revised operational practices concerning le guarding duties, teaching swimming lessons and delivering gymnastics in line with guidance issued by RLSS, Scottish Swimming and Scottish Gymnastics."The centre opening times currently scheduled for September  are:Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our customers for their continued loyalty and support. We are incredibly grateful for all of the messages of encouragement received.ldquoI would also like to extend my gratitude and appreciation to all enjoyleisure colleagues that have been working incredibly hard behind the scenes."Their tireless efforts have been instrumental in getting us to this point, which has included completely redefining our cleaning and safety standards, and reorganising our activity areas to comply with physical distancing at all of our centres and swimming pools.ldquoOur objective is to welcome and allow as many of our customers as possible, to safely access our gyms, swimming pools, exercise classes, sports and leisure activities.ldquoI hope by re-opening all our six sites, enjoyleisure is demonstrating to our customers that we remain absolutely committed to meeting our communitiesrsquo needs and enable many to be more active, more often with all the health advantages that that brings."We are hopeful we will be able to gradually increase capacities in our facilities in a phased manner, thus providing a safe, controlled and well-managed sport, health and fitness offering, which will enable us to methodically re-build the use of our facilities.ldquoWe know that our customers will have a lot of questions concerning the reopening of our facilities. There is a lot to tell you, and we promise we will do so over the coming weeks. Please look out for updates arriving in your email inbox and or posted onto our website enjoyleisure and social media pages."

title: coronavirus-scotlands-schools-pupils-staff-tested-positive
