title: furlough-no-plans-extend-scheme-businesses-closed-law
story: A Downing Street spokesman confirmed that the job-saving scheme is still set to be wound up by the end of October, despite mounting pressure to introduce a sector-specic plan.Labour and the SNP have both called for the Chancellor to extend the scheme to some areas, in particular those subject to local lockdowns and industries which have been worst hit by the pandemic.This includes manufacturing, retail and aviation.Today the Night Time Industries Association said afor clubs and venues is possiblenumbers inside are limited, social distancing takes place and clubbers wear face masks.Their report stated: "Use of face coverings on the dancefloor can be implemented and enforced through existing security staff and protocols.It also warned % of businesses in the sector could be closed by next month without more support. as the sector reaches a "critical point".Michael Kill, chief executive of the association, said: "We have now reached a critical point. In the absence of a clear reopening strategy from government, or the promise of financial support, huge numbers of businesses within our industry are facing financial collapse and thousands of job losses."The report clearly shows that there is a case for the safe reopening of night-time leisure venues, including nightclubs, late night bars, live music venues and event spaces."Whilst many of these are large capacity venues, it is important to note that they already have many of the safety protocols in place to mitigate the spread of Covid-."We implore the government to give us the opportunity to reopen in a safe, risk-assessed way."Last week Donald Macleod, who owns Glasgows Garage and Cathouse nightclubs, spoke of his fears of job losses and industry demisemore support was not given by the Scottish Government to help the night time economy.He said the furlough scheme alone was not enough to sustain the sector, and urged officials to step in.However Rishi Sunak has insisted it is unfair to continue the furlough scheme and give workers  hope about employment opportunities once it comes to an end.When askedfirms which are required to close by law would be able to use the furlough scheme after October st, a Downing street spokesman said: ""The chancellor has been clear when the furlough scheme comes to an end, but as I say we have provided support for businesses which they are able to use, and obviously we will continue to keep that under review."The treasury and the chancellor have set out support packages which ensure llots of these sorts of high risk areas will have received. We will keep it under continuous review but the chancellor has set out the support packages available to businesses."

title: green-light-100m-economy-boosting-joint-government-deal
story: The multi-million pound plan to boost the economy has been given the green light in Moray.Officials including Michael Matheson MSP and Iain Stewart MP signed the deals heads of terms agreement this morning, moving the plan a step forward.It signals a combined investment in the area of more than poundm, with projects receiving investment including the Grant Lodge visitor attraction in Elgin, a manufacturing base and a digital health and care centre in Moray.The area is currently represented in Westminster by new Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross, and in Holyrood by the SNPs Richard Lochhead.It is also where Boris Johnson chose to visit earlier this summer, becoming the first PM since Margaret Thatcher to do so.Moray council leader Graham Leadbitter welcomed the deal, saying it was "needed more than ever to help the local economy recover in the long-term from the COVID- crisis.Iain Stewart MP, Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Scotland for the UK Government said:ldquoEarlier this month I was delighted to announce the UK Government are investing poundm in the Moray Aerospace, Advanced Technology and Innovation Campus, which will create a pathway to skilled aviation engineering jobs for Morayrsquos residents.ldquoWith todayrsquos landmark signing of the pound million Moray Growth Deal I am pleased to confirm that the UK Governmentrsquos pound. million deal investment will also support the development of Grant Lodge - a visitor attraction in Elgin a Manufacturing Innovation base for Moray and a digital health and care cluster at Moray College.ldquoWorking together with the Scottish Government and local partners, we will deliver the prosperity and opportunities that the people of Moray deserve.ldquoCity Region and Growth Deals will be crucial to getting Scotlandrsquos economy back on track after the coronavirus pandemic and the UK Government has committed more than pound. billion to Growth Deals across every part of Scotland to secure the future of our economy.Michael Matheson MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity at the Scottish Government said: "Today marks an important milestone for the Moray Growth Deal, the signing of the Heads of Terms agreement and the confirmation of the projects supported by the pound. million the Scottish Government is investing in the deal."This will be invested in projects, designed by local partners, that can deliver on local priorities, re-invigorating the regional economy, and I appreciate all the hard work that Moray Council and their partners have put in to get us to this point.ldquoInvestments through the deal will create new jobs, protect existing jobs and extend economic opportunities to communities, businesses and iniduals across the region."At a time of such economic uncertainty and challenge, the projects and investment committed through the deal will be more important than ever."We will work with Moray Council over the coming months, to help them develop the projects to unlock investment and drive inclusive growth across the area as swtly as possible.Depute Chief Executive of Moray Council and lead officer for the Moray Growth Deal, Rhona Gunn, said the signing was a red-letter day for the area, adding that more work now had to be done to boost the case for the projects involved.She said: "ldquoWe still have much to do, and this work starts immediately to strengthen the business cases of each project and help shape the final outcomes. I and everyone  will be rolling up our sleeves to deliver this vision for Morayrsquos future prosperity.

title: downing-street-comments-bbc-plans-drop-rule-britannia-last-night-proms
story: It was revealed that the BBC is said to be discussing whether to drop Rule Britannia! and Land Of Hope And Glory from the finale.The Sunday Times said organisers fear a backlash because of the perceived association the traditional anthems have with colonialism and slavery.:Opinion: Mark Smith: Anti-Scottish  I think Irsquom finally facing up to my prejudiceNow Downing Street has entered into the controversy, while Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said he had written to the BBC over the issue.Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the PromsShare concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this with @BBCConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to itmdash Oliver DowdenAugust , The Prime Minister believes in tackling the ldquosubstance not the ldquosymbols of problems, a Number  spokesman said.ldquoThis is a decision and a matter for the organisers of the Proms and the BBC, the spokesman said.ldquoBut the PM previously has set out his position on like issues and has been clear that while he understands the strong emotions involved in these discussions, we need to tackle the substance of problems, not the symbols.Culture Secretary Mr Dowden said that ldquoconfident, forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history.He wrote on Twitter: ldquoRule Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the Proms.ldquo Share concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this withBBC.ldquoConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to it.Dalia Stasevska, from Finland, is conducting the Last Night this year, with soprano Golda Schultz and the BBC Symphony Orchestra performing.Actor Laurence Fox, who regularly criticises the BBC, wrote: ldquoI feel so honoured to be British and part of the incredible and erse modern nation we have become.ldquoWithout the past, we wouldnrsquot be where we are today. I wish the BBC would stop hating Britain so much. #DefundTheBBC.:Last Night of the Proms brought to a rousing finale with patriotic splendourBrexit Party leader Nigel Farage wrote: ldquoSo the BBC may drop Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory from The Proms because the Finnish conductor is too woke. Why not drop her instead  So the BBC may drop Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory from The Proms because the Finnish conductor is too woke. Why not drop her instead mdash Nigel FarageAugust , The BBC said in a statement: ldquoWe are still finalising arrangements for the Last Night Of Rhe Proms so that we are able to respond to the latest advice in regards to Covid- and deliver the best offering possible for audiences.ldquoWe have announced that conductor Dalia Stasevska, soprano Golda Schultz and the BBC Symphony Orchestra will perform at the Last Night Of The Proms this year. Full details will be announced nearer the time of the concert .Wasfi Kani, chief executive of Grange Park Opera in Surrey, told The Sunday Times she would supportthe removal of the songs.ldquoI donrsquot listen to Land Of Hope And Glory and say lsquothank God Irsquom Britishrsquo. It actually makes me feel more alienated. Britain raped India and that is what that song is celebrating, she said.

title: worldwide-covid-19-vaccination-rollout-in-interest-countries--
story: Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned against ldquovaccine nationalism and said global competition to create one could lead to prices spiking ldquoexponentially, which would only prolong the virus.Instead, he urged countries to support the Covax vaccines facility, which has the ldquolargest and most erse Covid- vaccine portfolio in the world.He told a WHO press briefing on Monday that  countries were ldquoengaging with the mechanism, which aims to deliver at least two billion vaccine doses by the end of .Dr Tedros said: ldquoWersquore working with vaccine manufacturers to provide all countries that join the effort timely and equitable access to all vaccines, licensed and approved.:Covid-: Indias coronavirus cases pass  millionldquoThis doesnrsquot just pool risk, it also means that prices will be kept as low as possible.ldquoNew research outlines that global competition for vaccine doses could lead to prices spiking exponentially in comparison to collaborative efforts, such as the Covax facility.ldquoIt would also lead to a prolonged pandemic as only a small number of countries would get most of the supply. Vaccine nationalism only helps the virus.Covax aims to ensure that low, middle and high-income countries all receive the vaccine in a ldquotimely way as soon as there is enough supply, Dr Tedros said.However, he warned that the schemersquos success hinged not only on countries signing up to it, but also ldquofilling key funding gaps for research and development work, and to support the lower-income economies involved."Our only way out of this #COVID pandemic is together."-@DrTedrosmdash World Health Organization August , ldquoThis is in the interests of all countries, even those that have invested with inidual manufacturers independently, Dr Tedros said.The WHO previously said the UK was one of several countries that had submitted ldquoexpressions of interest in the programme.Nine vaccines are currently part of the Covax portfolio, while discussions were ongoing with four other producers, Dr Tedros said.The scheme is being led by WHO, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovationsand the vaccine alliance Gavi.Health workers, those over , and people with certain diseases who are most at risk of dying with coronavirus will be the first to receive a vaccine, Dr Tedros added.ldquoAs supply increases, the next stage of the vaccine rollout would be expanded based on an assessment of each countryrsquos vulnerability to the virus, he said.:Furlough: No plans to extend scheme for businesses closed by lawldquoIn order to be able to secure enough doses to rollout the vaccines, the next step for the partnership is for countries to make binding commitments in support of the Covax facility.He said more funding was ldquourgently needed to move the ldquovaccine portfolio forward.Bruce Aylward, senior adviser to WHOrsquos director general, said countries need to submit an ldquoexpression of intent to join Covax by August , followed by confirmation of intent by September , and to have ldquoinitial payments in place by October .

title: coronavirus-scientists-claim-first-human-reinfected-covid-19
story: Researchers at the University of Hong KongrsquosLi Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine used genome sequencing to show that the patient had been infected by two ldquoclearly dferent virus strains.The patient is an ldquoapparently young and healthy -year-old man residing in Hong Kong.He was ing to the Asian city from Spain, travelling via the UK, when he was found to be positive for the coronavirus on August , .:Dossier reveals worst-case scenariono-deal Brexit and coronavirus coincideThe man had previously tested positive for the virus on March , , and was hospitalised with the disease three days later.He was discharged from hospital on April  following two negative tests for Covid- taken  hours apart.Researchers reported that the patient remained asymptomatic throughout his second infection, which occurred  days after the first.Experts cautioned against jumping to conclusions based on one single case but acknowledged the discovery was a concern.Announcing the result, researchers said: "An apparently young and healthy patient had a second episode of Covid- infection which was diagnosed . months after the first episode."This case illustrates that reinfection can occur just after a few months of recovery from the first infection. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV- may persist in the global human population as is the case for other common-cold associated human coronaviruses, evenpatients have acquired immunity via natural infection.ldquoSince the immunity can be short lasting after natural infection, vaccination should also be considered for those with one episode of infection.ldquoPatients with previous Covid- infection should also comply with epidemiological control measures such as universal masking and social distancing.The scientists add that, as immunity may be short-lasting, any vaccine should be administered to everyone, including those who have already been infected.If the research, published in the medical journalClinical Infectious Diseases, is correct it means thatherd immunity is ldquounlikely to be able to eliminate Covid-, and it will probably ldquocontinue to circulate through the population as ldquoseasonal coronaviruses do.Furthermore, they recommend that even those who have recovered from Covid-, and so are assumed to be unable to transmit the virus, should ldquocomply with epidemiological control measures such as universal masking and social distancing.:Coronavirus LIVE: Face coverings set to become mandatory in high school corridorsResponding to the study on Twitter, Yale School of Medicines Professor Akiko Iwasaki wrote: "Kudos to the scientists for this study. This is no cause for alarm - this is a textbook example of how immunity should work."Second infection was asymptomatic. While immunity was not enough to block re-infection, it protected the person from disease."Patient had no detectable antibody at the time of re-infection but developed detectable antibody after re-infection. This is encouraging."Since re-infection can occur, herd immunity by natural infection is unlikely to eliminate #SARSCoV. The only safe and effective way to achieve herd immunity is through vaccination."Lastly, while this is a good example of how primary infection can prevent disease from subsequent infection, more studies are needed to understand the range of outcomes from reinfection."The research was led by Dr Kelvin Kai-Wang To, Professor Ivan Fan-Ngai Hung, and Professor Kwok-Yung Yuen.Dr David Strain, from the University of Exeter said: ldquoThis is a worrying finding for several reasons. The first, as is laid out in this manuscript, is that it suggests that previous infection is not protective. The second is that it raises the possibility that vaccinations may not provide the hope that we have been waiting for.ldquoVaccinations work by simulating infection to the body, thereby allowing the body to develop antibodies. If antibodies dont provide lasting protection, we will need to revert to a strategy of viral near-elimination in order toto a more normal le.

title: handing-power-attorney-can-strengthen-close-bonds
story: One of the most enduring myths that humans perpetuate is that of the indestructability of their nearest and dearest: parents, grandparents and friends. True, le expectancy in the UK has increased steadily for decades, though the Office for National Statistics points out that it has signicantly levelled off since .And the current pandemic has jolted us all into a new sense of urgency, with increasing numbers deciding to make a will ndash a rise accompanied by a new interest in the power of attorney, which anticipates the possibility that someone, for reasons of age or health, may have to allow another to deal with their affairs.Scott Ewart, managing partner at Glasgow-based legal services firm Thomas Bradley and Co, believes that granting power of attorney is arguably even more important than making a will.ldquoSomeone losing capacity without having appointed an attorney ndash someone who can formally act on their behalf ndash could end up in a terrible situation.ldquoPeople often assume that when they write a will and appoint an executor, that person ndash often one of their children ndash will deal with all those issues including power of attorney but thats not the case, he says.ldquoWe can advise them about the dference between a will, which takes care of your affairs after you have passed away and a power of attorney that ensures your affairs are taken care of should you lose the capacity to manage them yourself.There are two types of power of attorney in Scotland: that relating to financial property affairs which you can decide to begin immediately or onlyyou become incapable and welfare power of attorney, which allows someone to make welfare decisions for you should you lose the capacity to make these decisions.Incapacity, Ewart points out, can affect the simplest aspects of le. ldquoPeople tend to think in terms of a crisis, such as someone being affected by Alzheimerrsquos, but power of attorney can be important for someone who is just struggling physically, he says.ldquoI think of my grandmother who at  is mentally as sharp as a tack but set up a power of attorney as through illness she simply wasnrsquot able get out to take care of basic essentials such as going to the post office for her pension. Someone may also need their son or daughter to make sure gas or electricity bills are looked after and that the shopping is done.Which means that the person granted powers of attorney must be someone you can trust implicitly ndash and someone who also feels comfortable with acting formally on anotherrsquos behalf. Some people find it dficult to discuss with a parent that they face losing capacity through an illness."So the right person isnrsquot just someone you trust but someone who can also handle the potential emotional stress of a being an attorney, he says.Appointing an attorney can be a sensitive matter but the person granted power can subsequently be altered. ldquoPeople can and do come to us after several years ndash and after circumstances have altered ndash to change the person in whom power of attorney resides or add someone , but most people tend to appoint their children or grandchildren, he says.ldquoAnd they try to share the responsibility between two or three people, making the person best able to deal with their affairs the primary attorney, with one or two substitutes.ldquoIf there are no substitutes in place and the principal attorney passes away or moves to another country after the person who has appointed them loses capacity then no one  can be appointed, he adds.The Office of the Public provides the registration service for powers of attorney and can help people who have no knowledge of whatrsquos involved. Ewart explains: ldquoTherersquos a lot of support for the many people who initially have no idea what to do and the OPG ensures that people who grant powers of attorney or put them in place are protected and that trust companies are doing their job properly.ldquoIt receives a one-off fee for that and is always there to give general advice on what you should or shouldnrsquot do, thoughlegal or financial advice is needed you should consult an appropriate adviser.And while itrsquos possible for an inidual to set up a power of attorney, Ewart says itrsquos a complicated process that involves solicitors and GPs ensuring that multiple documents are signed off correctly by the persons family members. ldquoEngaging a professional who can complete the process online removes the most onerous part of the exercise, making sure itrsquos dated, checked and signed off correctly and most importantly, that itrsquos registered, he says.The company has seen a signicant increase in requests for powers of attorney: ldquoItrsquos becoming a priority for more people and % to % of the people we talk to about wills every month now set up a power of attorney at the same time.He says that while this does not represent a major financial decision, many people are seeing their incomes squeezed at the moment so Thomas Bradley is currently halving its price for the service. ldquoWhile recognising that ndash like every other company ndash we must make money I feel we have an obligation not to have profits solely in mind at the moment and offer a service thatrsquos affordable. If wersquore going to do something positive for the community, now is the time to do it.thomasbradleyco

title: humiliating-leaked-labour-memo-party-branded-morris-minor-politics
story: Confidential documents prepared ahead of the  General Election advised the party should target seats in England and Wales rather than attempt to win back seats from the SNP.The SNP have jumped on the leak, which was circulated online, saying it shows the party is "finished" in Scotland and describing it as the "Morris Minor of politics".Scottish Labour party sources told The Herald the document was "humiliating, particularly in its outdated references to religion and the assumption that we shouldnt be trying to win against the SNP.":Kevin McKenna: There is a reason why Scottish Labour is dyingThe key seats strategy" document states: "There is no evidence that organisational investment in Scottish seats will deliver improved electoral outcomes and there is abundant evidence from the analysis of recent general elections that spending money in contests where we are not competitiveis a much less efficient way of achieving changed electoral outcomes than investing in tighter electoral contests where in Britain.ldquoTo achieve any given small percentage increase in vote share for Labour in a seat in Scotland where we are not regarded by the electorate as a serious rival to the incumbent requires a substantially larger investment of human and financial resources than in a seat in England or Wales where we are so regarded.On constituency and polling data, it states: " There were dferences for Scotland, where data availability is slightly more limited."Some constituency-level demographics, such as employment categories and percentage in poor health, were absent."However, one iable ndash proportion of Catholic residents by constituencyndash was included for Scotland for the purpose of helping to distinguish better between Labour and SNP supporters."Currently, Labour only have one MP in Scotland - the partys shadow secretary of state Ian Murray.Party leader Richard Leonard has come under fire from within Scottish Labour in recent months, with accusations that he is not well-known enough or is not cutting through with voters.:"Utterly humiliating" defeat for Richard Leonard as executive rejects IndyRef conference proposalLast week Mr Leonard made a key note speech setting out his vision for Scotland - a move which was widely thought to be an attempt to boost his profile.He has been plagued by leaks from within his own party and briefings against him since he took over as leader in .SNP Western Isles MP Angus MacNeil said: ldquoLabour are finished in Scotland. They are the Morris Minor of politics, people sort of remember them, occasionally fondly, but no one will travel in them again.SNP MSP David Torrance said: ldquoLabour are a busted flush and all but irrelevant in Scottish politics. This leaked document is further evidence,needed, that their support base has totally collapsed in their former heartlands.ldquoThe partyrsquos leadership is completely out of touch with working families in Scotland. The longer they choose to cover their ears, and side with the Tories in an attempt to deny voters a say on their future, the further down the polls they will slide.:Richard Leonard: Scottish Labour determined to pull togetherA Scottish Labour spokesman said: ldquoThis document clearly shows that a number of seats in Scotland were prioritised during the  UK General Election campaign and the Scottish campaign received support throughout.ldquoAs Richard Leonard leads Scottish Labour into the  Scottish Parliament elections, we are fighting for every vote and every seat. Our bold policy  calls for a Green New Deal, a National Care Service and a quality Jobs Guarantee Scheme.

title: sturgeons-top-official-agress-answer-blocked-salmond-inquiry-question
story: Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans has told the Holyrood harassment inquiry she was ldquovery willing to write to it on the subject.Last week, Ms Evans refused to answer a question from Tory MSP Murdo Fraser on whether female civil servants were ldquoadvised not to be alone with the former FM.Shaking her head, Ms Evans replied: ldquoI canrsquot comment on that.As the question was based on disputed evidence at Mr Salmondrsquos criminal trial, SNP convener Linda Fabiani then blocked the question as outside the inquiryrsquos remit.That prompted a public spat with other MSPs arguing the question was legitimate, as the inquiry is looking at the ldquoculture within the Scottish Government.Mr Salmond was acquitted of  counts of sexual assault in March, but evidence emerged of inappropriate and drunken behaviour with female staff.Two days after the committee row, Mr Fraser asked Ms Sturgeonshe was aware of female civil servants being advised not to be alone with her predecessor.She told the Scottish Parliament: ldquoNo, I was not aware of that.Ahead of the inquiryrsquos second evidence session tomorrow, Ms Evans has now changed her position.In a letter to Ms Fabiani, she said: ldquoI fully appreciate you will have had reasons, based on the Committeersquos remit and the ious legal restrictions in place, for disallowing that line of questioning."However, I would like to make clear that - contrary to some media reports - I am very willing to write to the Committee to address this issue.The inquiry is examining the Governmentrsquos botched in-house sexual misconduct probe into Mr Salmond in , which was triggered by complaints from two female civil servants.Mr Salmond had the exercise set aside in a judicial review, forcing ministers to admit it had been unfair, unlawful and ldquotainted by apparent bias.The collapse of the Governmentrsquos case in January  left taxpayers with a pound, bill for Mr Salmondrsquos costs, and the Holyrood inquiry is investigating what happened.The MSPs are also looking at whether Ms Sturgeon broke the Scottish ministerial code by staying in contact with Mr Salmond while her officials were investigating him.Mr Fraser welcomed Ms Evansrsquos statement, but said she should oral evidence on the subject rather than just put it in writing.He said: ldquoLeslie Evans has certainly changed her tune since she refused to answer my question.ldquoBut we donrsquot need Leslie Evans to merely write to the committee.ldquoGiven her attempt to dodge the question at the first time of asking, it is only right she now appears before the inquiry again, as soon as possible, to face the scrutiny she avoided the first time.ldquoThere can be no hiding behind a letter for Ms Evans on when she knew about claims that female civil servants were not allowed to be alone with Alex Salmond.

title: jeane-freeman-stand-next-holyrood-election
story: Announcing her decisionto her constituency association on Monday evening Ms Freeman said: "After very careful thought I have decided not to stand for re-selection as the SNP candidate for Carrick, Cumnock and Doon Valley in the  Scottish Parliament elections," she said, in a statement."It has been a real privilege and pleasure to represent the Ayrshire I grew up in and which in so many ways, made me who I am today. I have also been privileged to hold two ministerial offices in the Scottish Government in that time,initially charged with setting up Scotlandrsquos first social security service and now as Cabinet Secretary for Health.: Jeane Freeman expects very signicant increase in waiting lists as NHS restarts"In Government and as a local MSP for a great constituency, I have learned a great deal and have had the opportunity to work with very many talented, committed and compassionate people."I will be  later this year and  by the end of the next parliamentary term and while I have a great deal of energy left and more I want to do, I think it is the right time for me to stand aside and let another take forward the work as an MSP for this constituency.Carrick, Cumnock and Doon Valley is a beautul part of our country and it is full of talented, enterprising and hard working people.It will be an honour for whoever wins the constituency seat, as it has been for me.Sorry to hear that @JeaneFMSP is standing down. Irsquom sure she still has a big role in Scotlandrsquos future."I have been hugely supported by SNP members in Carrick, Cumnock and Doon Valley and I am grateful to them all.I owe a particular debt to my hardworking and excellent constituency staff, Tracy, Paul and Jayde without whom I literally couldnrsquot have done the job.I have informed my local Constituency Association tonight that I will not be seeking re-selection for the next Scottish Parliament election in May . pic OxHFrpJih"In the months ahead I will continue my focus on the work we need to do as a country to meet the challenges facing us all in dealing with COVID-, supporting our NHS and social care workers, and in re-mobilising our NHS and social care services to the greatest extent possible.":Sturgeons top official agrees to answer blocked Salmond inquiry questionShe added:"I remain even firmer in my conviction that the right future for the people of this constituency and of Scotland is one where we have all the democratic and decision-making powers of a normal country. All good wishes for the future. https:t.co GGLSFwYc"Securing independence by securing the right of people in Scotland to choose their own future will allow us to build on the progressive work of the SNP government since  and fulfil the potential of this place and this country to build the prosperous, inclusive and progressive future we want for all of us and for future generations."Gutted @JeaneFMSP is not standing for re-election. title: rule-britannia-feature-last-night-proms-bbc-confirms
story: The confirmation comes after The Sunday Times said organisers feared a backlash because of the perceived association the traditional anthems have with colonialism and slavery.Downing Street waded into the controversy and Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said he had written to the BBC over the issue.:Downing Street comments on BBC plans to drop Rule Britannia from Last Night of the PromsRule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the PromsShare concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this with @BBCConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to itmdash Oliver DowdenAugust , A statement from the BBC on Monday evening said: ldquoWith much reduced musical forces and no live audience, the Proms will curate a concert that includes familiar, patriotic elements such as Jerusalem and the national anthem, and bring in new moments capturing the mood of this unique time, including Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone, presenting a poignant and inclusive event for .Dalia Stasevska, from Finland, is conducting the Last Night this year, with soprano Golda Schultz and the BBC Symphony Orchestra performing.The corporationrsquos statement said: ldquoWe very much regret the unjustied personal attacks on Dalia Stasevska, BBC Symphony Orchestra principal guest conductor, made on social media and where.ldquoAs ever, decisions about the Proms are made by the BBC, in consultation with all artists involved.The BBC said a new arrangement of Jerusalem will be performed, along with orchestral versions of Land Of Hope And Glory and Rule Britannia!.In the statement, the broadcaster said: ldquoThe programme will include a new arrangement by Errollyn Wallen of Hubert Parryrsquos Jerusalem alongside new orchestral versions of Pomp And Circumstance March No.  lsquoLand Of Hope And Gloryrsquoand Rule Britannia! as part of the Sea Songs, as Henry Wood did in .Earlier, a Number  spokesman said the Prime Minister believes in tackling the ldquosubstance not the ldquosymbols of problems.ldquoThis is a decision and a matter for the organisers of the Proms and the BBC, the spokesman said.ldquoBut the PM previously has set out his position on like issues and has been clear that while he understands the strong emotions involved in these discussions, we need to tackle the substance of problems, not the symbols.Culture Secretary Mr Dowden said that ldquoconfident, forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history.He wrote on Twitter: ldquoRule Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the Proms.ldquo Share concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this withBBC.ldquoConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to it.

title: coronavirus-nicola-sturgeon-asks-public-bear-us-testing
story: The First Minister asked people to ldquobear with us while ldquoissues at the system, which is run by the UK Government, were corrected after a weekend of high demand.It followed reports of multiple technical problems with the booking system, including people in Edinburgh being advised their nearest testing centre was in Newcastle.The BBC reported some Glasgow residents were being offered tests in Stranraer instead of Glasgow airport.Ms Sturgeon said there appeared to have been a surge in parents seeking tests for children who had shown cold symptoms after ing to school.Interim chief medical officer Dr Gregor Smith said there also appeared to have been an increase in people with no symptoms at all seeking tests.The opposition parties demandedMs Sturgeon and her ministers get to the bottom of the problem.At the daily briefing, Ms Sturgeon insisted the testing system was generally ldquoworking well, but also said officials were looking into glitches.She said: ldquoI am aware of some issues with the booking system this morning.ldquoWe have seen exceptional testing demand over the weekend and therefore we are looking right now at how we ensure that demand is properly and appropriately managed.She said officials were still investigating, but people in Scotland may have ldquoerroneously been directed to testing centres in England rather than the next available slot in Scotland.The First Minister continued: ldquoOur testing system is obviously working, itrsquos working well, but as demand increases or at periods of high demand bear with us as we resolve and understand any particular issues.She said anecdotal accounts suggested many parents were taking their children to be tested after they developed coughs.She said: ldquoWersquore going into a part of the year when people could have other illnesses and viruses that present with similar symptoms to Covid.ldquoSo we expect to see demand for testing increasing as we go into the autumn and winter and there will undoubtedly be peaks in that demand period.Dr Smith said it was not uncommon to see more cases of coughs or colds as children ed to school after the summer.He said: ldquoI think itrsquos inevitable that as you bring people back together, particularly as you restart schools, you get a rebound in the volume of respiratory symptoms.As a GP for many years, this was very common whenever schools went back.He said anyone with coronavirus symptoms should immediately book a test and self-isolate. However those were asymptomatic should book a test onlyadvised to do so by the Test and Protect team.Tory MSP Donald Cameron said: ldquoItrsquos not right that some people are being sent on -mile round-trips and across the border for a Covid test.ldquoWersquove been hearing from constituents that testing sites are struggling to cope with demand, and test results that should be delivered in  hours are taking several days.ldquoYoung people and teachers have already had their lives disrupted considerably.Itrsquos vital that they can get back to work and school as safely and as soon as possible.ldquoI urge the Scottish Government to find out whatrsquos gone wrong here and work quickly to maintain public confidence in the testing system.Labour MSP Monica Lennon said: ldquoSomething has gone horribly wrong that Scots are being sent to Belfast and Cumbria for Covid- tests.ldquoOnly last week the Health Secretary said that testing is key to actively hunting down the virus - but instead people are having to hunt down a test.ldquoIt isnrsquot good enough and the Scottish Government needs to fulfil its promises on testing.Liberal Democrat MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton said: ldquoThis is an extremely concerning development. We know how important it is to test quickly and contain the spread of this virus.ldquoPeople need to have trust in the system and be provided with accurate information about the nearest test centre.ldquoIt would be disastrouspeople displaying symptoms travel longer distances than they should.ldquoThe Health Secretary must get to the root of this problem urgently. We canrsquot afford for the system to fall down whenever demand increases.SNP Inverclyde councillor Chris McEleny said people in his area had been offered tests in Northern Ireland.He said: ldquoMy casework over the weekend highlighted that there has been a clear upsurge in demand for testing.ldquo However itrsquos not acceptable that people in Inverclyde are being asked to travel outwith our area to get a test when there is a test centre in Inverclyde.ldquoIt beggars belief that the UK Governmentrsquos test system was asking our community to travel to Northern Ireland to receive a test.ldquoEven discounting that utterly unacceptable situation, itrsquos also not good enough to expect people to travel to sites in Lochgilphead and Edinburgh.ldquoWe must have testing in our community and it is clear that we need to have a system in place that district nurses are deployed to test young children as opposed to asking parents to travel great s to then have to administer the test themselves.

story: An application to extend Cursiter Quarry in Firth has been rejected by Orkney Islands Council#s planning committee, today, Wednesday.The application, put forward by OIC#s development and infrastructure department, received letters of objection from four residents living in the nearby area. Reasons for objection included:After a y discussion, councillors chose to reject the application. This decision was led by Kirkwall East councillor, David Dawson, who was seconded by West Mainland councillor, Owen Tierney. title: local livestock association enters in to new partnership
story: Orkney Livestock Associationhave signed up to partner with the Moredun scientic institute to give their members access to research outputs, knowledge, skills and expertise generated by the Organisation.OLA is a farmer-led organisation aimed at improving the health of Orkney’s cattle herds.  The scheme was officially launched in February  with a programme to eradicate BVD and a Johne’s eradication scheme followed in November . The new partnership will allow OLA#s members access to Moredun’s members area with a wealth of livestock health information, including the full range of technical news sheets, and will also promote working together on joint events and initiatives.The work of the Moredun scientic institute have made a major impact both in the UK and globally, due in a large part to the unique relationship it has had has with the farming community and the emphasis the organisation puts on effective knowledge exchange with livestock producers.Retired local vet Willie Stewart, who is the chairman of Moredun’s North of Scotland Regional Advisors Board said:“The Moredun Research Institute is a world leader in the development of livestock vaccines, animal disease tests and control plans. I believe that OLA representing the cattle industry in Orkney can have a strong association with Moredun in the future.#Beth Wells, from Moredun, said “Through meetings we have been fortunate to meet many of Orkney’s livestock farmers, who are well known for their high quality beef production and we are delighted to be developing a closer working collaboration with OLA, which will be of huge benefit to both of our organisations.”OLA is a sub-group of HiHealth Herdcare which is a national cattle health scheme. Karen Johnston, from OLA, said: “We are delighted and very honoured to give our members the opportunity to benefit from expert information and support from such a prestigious and well respected organisation.  We are looking forward to seeing how this partnership progresses and the benefits it brings to Orkney farmers.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur calls for paramedic students bursary
story: newsMcArthur calls for paramedic students# bursaryAugust ,  at : amOrkney MSP, Liam McArthur has pressed the Scottish Government to commit to introducing a bursary scheme to support student paramedics.During First Minister’s Questions, yesterday, Thursday, Mr McArthur highlighted that Scottish students studying to become paramedics are asked to work the same hours as a fully qualied paramedic during the course of their degree.According to the Orkney MSP, this makes part time work almost impossible, yet trainee paramedics are not given bursary funding in recognition of this.Mr McArthur has previously raised this with the Scottish Government but was told that there were no plans to amend the funding options.In response, the First Minister acknowledged the case being made and gave an assurance that the government would continue to consider how better support could be made available to trainee paramedics.Following the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “Paramedics play a vital role within our NHS, but this is not reflected in the support they are given to become qualied.“Like student nurses and midwives, trainee paramedics now need to complete a degree course while also working similar hours to a fully qualied paramedic. Unlike student nurses and midwives, however, those training to be a paramedic are not eligible for a bursary, despite being unable to take up part time work.  To add insult to injury, their counterparts in England do receive bursaries.“This lack of a level playing field risks putting off those we need to see coming into our health service.  The current arrangements do little to encourage young people to pursue a career as a paramedic and store up problems for the future.“When I wrote to the Health Secretary recently on behalf of a constituent, I was told the government has no plans to review the funding options for trainee paramedics. Today, Nicola Sturgeon said she would look into the matter, having also been approached by a young constituent, angry at the unequal treatment.“The First Minister needs to recognise that introducing a bursary scheme would make a real dference, not least in widening access to the profession.  It’s time the Scottish Government properly recognised the dedication of our trainee paramedics by putting them on the same footing as trainee nurses and midwives.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur demands clarity on ret timeline
story: newsMcArthur demands clarity on RET timelineAugust ,  at : pmOrkney MSP, Liam McArthur has demanded clarity from the Scottish Government on when Road Equivalent Tarfwill be delivered on Pentland Firth routes.During Portfolio Questions, today, Thursday, Mr McArthur pressed the island minister, Paul Wheelhouse to confirm a date for its introduction now that the courts and European Commission appear to have removed any objections to it proceeding.Mr McArthur believes that cheaper fares should have been implemented on Northern Isles routes over two years ago, and has repeated calls for ministers to commit the underspend from this delay to reduce fares on Orkney’s internal ferry services.In response, Mr Wheelhouse confirmed that the Scottish Government were continuing to engage with the European Commission on options for introducing RET but said that this work had been paused because of the COVID- pandemic.Following the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “For over a decade those travelling on ferry routes to the Western Isles have benefited from cheaper ferry fares while Orkney has been excluded.“During this time, the excuses from Ministers may have changed but sadly not the experience for many using these leline routes. On the Pentland Firth, people are still being forced to pay over the odds.“COVID has inevitably created challenges, but even prior to the pandemic there seemed to be little urgency from the Scottish Government to deliver on its promise. Assurances that Ministers will now ‘pick up the ball again’ are likely to ring hollow with islanders who just want a date for cheaper fares to be introduced.“Meantime, Ministers could help soften the blow from the delayed introduction of RET by using the underspend to cut fares on Orkney’s internal ferry services. title: scotland remains in phase three but more activities to resume
story: coronavirusScotland remains in Phase Three — but more activities to resumeAugust ,  at : pmScotland is to remain in Phase Three of its lockdown exit plan — but facilities such as gyms and swimming pools will be allowed to open from August , First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced, this afternoon, Thursday.The reopening of bingo halls, and the restarting of outdoor contact sports and live events and driving lessons will be allowed from next Monday, August .#On balance, taking account of dferent harms that COVID and the restrictions imposed to tackle it are inflicting on the country, we have proposed that reopenings pencilled in for August  can proceed,# Ms Sturgeon said.#I must stress, though, that such reopenings must only happen when the appropriate guidance covering that activity or setting has been implemented.#We will also monitor the impact carefully, and we will not hesitate to reimpose restrictions, should that prove necessary.#She added that, subject to guidance being in place, indoor swimming and gym facilities will also be able to reopen from August .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: tenth case linked to orkney covid cluster
story: breaking newsTenth case linked to Orkney COVID clusterAugust ,  at : pmA tenth crew member has tested positive for COVID- in the Orkney fishing vessel cluster, NHS Orkney’s Director of Public Health Dr Louise Wilson confirmed today, Friday.This was disclosed in her update to the multi-agency Incident Management Team , this afternoon.The crew member is in isolation on the Scottish mainland and being monitored by the relevant health boardAs he does not live in Orkney, this new case will not be reflected in the Scottish Government COVID figures for the isles.Dr Wilson said the IMT would meet again only when there was new information to report. “All contacts of those involved in this cluster have now been traced but we will continue to monitor the situation,” she said.Dr Wilson reminded the Orkney community that near neighbour, Aberdeen, was still in lockdown and not to become complacent about the spread of COVID-.“By following the FACTS guidance, a person decreases their risk of contracting and passing on the virus,” she added.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mareel to open its cinema at reduced capacity and with no new blockbusters
story: Film fans have been told to  expect changes when Mareel opens its cinema again later this week.Jenny Leask, film programme manager, said that while she was #absolutely delighted# to be reopening on Friday, there would also be restrictions.Writing in a blog, Ms Leask said films would only be showing in cinema one as physical distancing requirement meant it was not practical to reopen cinema two. As a result, fewer films will be on show, to begin with.Ms Leask also said regular slots, such as Screen Horizons # which showcases independent and world cinema, classic films and documentaries # will not be running, although they are hoped to#as soon as possible#. on release as, due to the distribution deal, it would be the only film we could show for two weeks, and we want to cater for as many of you as possible,# she added.#No new titles have been released in the summer, with all the cinemas closed, but there were plenty of films we were scheduled to show before lockdown so we#re now able to catch up with those.#I#ve tried to include a wide iety of films in our programme, so hopefully there#ll be something for everyone.#Bookings can only be made online until the building reopens. The system is set up to to automatically block off seats around each booking, keeping the appropriate distance between customers.Customers making group bookings are asked to ensure all the people in that group are in the same bubble –  and to book tickets at the same timethey want to sit together.Face coverings must be worn in the cinema other than when eating or drinking. Customers are asked to take their own rubbish with them at the end of the film and put it in the bins provided.Cinemas will be thoroughly cleaned between each screening and hand sanitiser is available throughout the building.#We#ll keep you posted on any new developments, and please rest assured we#re all working hard to make your visit a safe and enjoyable one,# Ms Leask said.#See you at the cinema.#..Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. title: instead of jumping on the bandwagon i should have trusted the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineNow there is much within the machinations that occupy the precious time of our Comhairle officers that could well be regarded as relatively ‘trivial’, although I will fully concede that even the most improbable deliberations might well form the centre of somebody’s entire universe.But when we, as a community, or section of that community, continue to press for answers and resolutions to a subject that has already been explained fully to us, then we should ask ourselves one important question: “Are we doing this for the greater good, or because we are trying to promote our own agenda ”. about some of the material that was included in the Scottish Government’s RSHPguidelines and how I felt that some of it was completely over the top for inclusion in any classroom.Several concerned parents had written to me, asking what on earth was going on.I enquired of both the Director and Chair of Education and Children’s Services as to the validity of these concerns.I was happy to note that the ‘plot’ wasn’t as sinister as had been portrayed by some ‘concerned’ groups both within the counciland on anti-social media.Some alleged that the Comhairle were somehow, through the back-door and under the cover of the Covid- crisis , trying to sneak through an agenda which went against the “moral values of this community”.An inflammatory accusation, one that was sure to ignite passions and ring yet another Pavlovian bell.Except that, far from being subject matter that was about to get rammed down our children’s throats, not just ‘promoted’ it was simply an extreme example of what was included for reference, should anyone wish to avail themselves of it.Yes, some of it was fairly graphic stuff and, as I’ve said before, I was hugely alarmed that it was even considered for anything to be found in our classrooms.But, as is the case with material which has been taught in our schools for at least a couple of centuries the devil is in the detail .Luckily we have seen teachers, historically, opt to use the message of love, forgiveness, compassion and mutual understanding from this particular tome ignoring the more sinister aspects where death, retribution, punishment and all kinds of nastiness are very much front and centre.Choosing your testaments wisely is what this is primarily about.We are lucky to have an educational framework where common sense prevails, otherwise there could be very many distractions in the subjects of Biology, Geology and quite possibly Physics.I attempted to be amusing about a topic which has very legitimate, obvious, and serious, implications for our most impressionableyoung people.I hoped I was taking a cue from people who think that a banana dipped into a jar of Nutella is a suitable metaphor for something.Possibly the obesity crisis I think a jar of Bovril might have been funnier.If people wish to identy as a Unicorn and have sex with the pavement, then that’s fine too, but not surely for inclusion in ‘guidance’ material.Yes, I have to admit that I also jumped onto the bandwagon, until I had the situation clearly explained to me and was told to trust the teacher’.They will be given the ultimate discretion and they know best what’s appropriate for their young audience.We do ‘much ado’ well here.When ‘Ironside’ and ‘Bob the Budget Builder’ steered the Comhairle and helped many local businesses through the worst of the effects of the ongoing pandemic, we turned inward and focused on upholstery.With Bernie, Angus and the Education Department, all under immense pressure to get a hugely problematic school year underway on time, we are more focused on what won’tbe getting taught, rather than what will, and how.Andour kids come home from school with a penchant for strange combinations of fruit and nut sandwiches, then it will have been discussed with the Head Teacher and Parent Council first.A lot of the contentious issues which occupy us here in the Western Islesare perceived to exist somewhere between a conservative, culturally protective, radically Christian, ‘right’, and a somewhat more progressive, more liberal, secular, bunch of left-wing snowflakes.Most of us are somewhere, far more certainly and squarely, in the middle trying to make sense of it all.If we cannot empower and trust our teachers to do what’s best for the most vulnerable amongst us, then we will have failed both.The man of the week, last week, certainly in the northern half of this county, was the irrepressible David Black.Three rounds crammed into  hours saw him claim the Thompson Bruce Trophy at Stornoway and take an early lead in Scarista’s  ‘Blue-Riband’ event.Rounds of +  around Lady Lever Park on Friday and Saturday saw him edge out Eddie Rogers,  +  by just a single shot over  holes.A further shot adrt saw Murdo ‘Griddy’ MacLeod,  +  in third slot.Iain ‘Juke Box’ MacKay won the handicap trophy with two excellent rounds of nett  for a  total.In between his Thompson Bruce exploits, Davie also posted the leading score in the, two-round, Harris G.C. Club Championship.His  was  shots ahead of nearest challengers, Billy Fraser and Cal Robertson, both on .Starting with six straight pars, he succumbed to bogies at the ‘amen’ of corners, the deadly-deceiving brace of par-s at   .Naturally he bounced straight back birdies at the new th, and the th brought him back to level.He swapped a birdie for a bogey at  and  to see him home safely.Only a sht in plate tectonics will see him throw away this lead.Midweek at Stornoway saw the Glennie Trophy claimed by Iain Moir on  Stableford Points. Starting his opening four holes, five-over par, couldn’t have been good for his confidence.He was just one-over for the next .In the Junior section, Calum Gbounced back from his recent humblings at the hands of brother, Geordie H in the Par Bogey competition.Six ahead of the course, he demolished the rest of the field by  clear shots.In the Scarista midweek competition, Billy Fraser kept up his, season-long, decent form, partnering Chris Sutton to a fine win in the Pairs Greensomes.Their  was two ahead of Russell Tennant and Alan Gunn’s, .Benbecula’s finest continue to battle it out for their season-long Order of Merit, Dami Steele ing a semblance of normality, bouncing back from a week out of the top spots to consolidate his lead at the top.His round wasn’t, however, good enough to claim the full points last Tuesday evening, Domhnall MacKay storming to a -pointer and the maximum Point haul.Apparently Donald has been keeping his powderdry and intends, after a decent sabbatical, to make a strong charge over the coming weeks.

title: litir do luchd ionnsachaidh
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine.’. Rugadh e sa mhansa ann am Blàr Athall ann an seachd ceud deug, seasgad ʼs a ceithir . Aig aois trì-deug, chaidh e a dh’Oilthigh Chill Rìmhinn. Aig aois ochd-deug, thòisich e mar oileanach Diadhachd.Chòrd e ris gu mòr a bhith air ais air a’ Ghàidhealtachd. Shaoil e gun robh na coilltean beithe timcheall a’ mhansa air leth brèagha. Agus ghabh an coitheanal ris mar mhinistear. Bha e dìreach fichead ʼs a dhà bliadhna a dh’aois. thairis air a’ gheamhradh. Thug sin ùine dha airson an leabhar-gràmair aige a sgrìobhadh. Chaidh fhoillseachadh ann an ochd ceud deug ʼs a h-aon .Ged a bha Mgr Stiùbhart na mhinistear, bha rudeigin a dhìth air gu spioradail, dha rèir fhèin. Fhuair e dùsgadh thairis air dà latha anns an Ògmhios seachd ceud deug, naochad ʼs a sia . Thàinig an soisgeulaiche Sasannach, Teàrlach Simeon, à Cambridge, a dh’fhuireach sa mhansa ann am Maoilinn. Bha Mgr Stiùbhart dhen bheachd gun robh Dia air Teàrlach Simeon a chur thuige mar theachdaire. Bho sin a-mach, bha taobh soisgeulach aig Alasdair Stiùbhart nach robh air a bhith aige roimhe.. Bha Alasdair a-nise a’ fàs ainmeil. Trì bliadhna an dèidh bàs a mhnà, fhuair e cuireadh bho ghrunn mhinistearan a dhol a Shiorrachd Rois. Bha e a’ fuireach aig ministear anns an Eilean Dubh, an t-Urr. Teàrlach Calder. An ceann greis, phòs e an nighean a bu shine aig Mgr Calder. Ann an ochd ceud deug ʼs a còig , fhuair e litir bhon a h-uile comhairliche air Comhairle Baile Inbhir Pheofharain, a’ toirt cuireadh dha a bhith na mhinistear an sin.Ann an ochd ceud ʼs a dhà-dheug , thàinig an dàrna eagran dhen leabhar-ghràmair aige a-mach. Bha Alasdair Stiùbhart a-nise cliùiteach mar sgoilear Gàidhlig. Dh’iarr an t-Urr. Iain Stiùbhart ann an Lus air Alasdair a bheachdan a thoirt seachad air ath-nuadhachadh a’ Bhìobaill Ghàidhlig. Agus dh’iarr Comunn Gàidhealach na h-Alba air faclair Gàidhlig a chur ri chèile. Ach dhiùlt e, oir bha e ro thrang mar mhinistear.  Cha robh e toilichte ann an Inbhir Pheofharain, ge-tà, agus dh’fhuiling e call dòchais, no eadhon tinneas-inntinn air choreigin. Ghluais e a Dhùn Èideann, far an robh e na mhinistear aig a’ Chanongate, agus chaochail e an sin anns a’ Chèitean ochd ceud deug, fichead ʼs a h-aon . Bidh mòran ga chuimhneachadh mar mhinistear. Bidh gu leòr eile ga chuimhneachadh mar fhear de phrìomh sgoilearan Gàidhlig a linne. Sàr-Pheairteach am measg sàr-Pheairtich eile a thug cliù do ar cànan prìseil.* * * * *

title: island pupil highlights exam unfairness after being downgraded in all five
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineEva Peteranna, a fth year pupil at Sgoil Lionacleit in Benbecula, has written a letter outlining her own situation to Scottish education secretary John Swinney.In the letter she reveals that in all five of her Highers she was downgraded from the award she had been predicted to achieve.In one subject a predicted grade of B was ed as a fail. The rest were reduced by a single grade and she has missed out on As in English, Biology and Modern Studies, as well as a C in Higher Chemistry.Eva said to have her grades knocked down so signicantly has made her “completely reconsider her career path”.Exams were cancelled this year because of Covid- and replaced with estimated grades based on past attainment, and the school’s previous exam record.The modelling system adapted by the Scottish Qualications Authority reduced the grades of around , results, with analysis suggesting youngsters from poorer backgrounds and historically poorer performing schools suffered disproportionately.In her letter, shared almost , times on Twitter, Eva said that “it was clear” that her grades had been signicantly adjusted “because I go to a school classed as underperforming”.Her letter calls for the system, which she describes as discriminatory, to be urgently investigated, adding: “The government has been pushing the ‘no wrong path slogan’ but why should pupils from disadvantaged backgrounds and deprived areas be forced into a pathway they didn’t want and worked tirelessly to avoid”.Eva had been predicted in her fourth year to achieve  As and two Cs at national five level, but in her exams she improved to come out with five As and a B.She added that her school’s recent performance had been affected by staff shortages.She had stayed behind after school for extra tuition, aiming to secure a university place and a career in the field of medicine.“Any further efforts by pupils to achieve higher grades in schools which have historically underperformed has been disregarded, she added.“SQA results this year have been more about fitting the statistical trends than the inidual pupil.”According to the Scottish Government#s own statistics, the estimated . per cent of most deprived pupils who would have expected an A-C band at Higher was lowered to . per cent by the SQA#s moderation system. By contrast, for the least deprived pupils, the predicted . per cent for A-C grades was lowered to . per cent.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Tuesday that it would not be “credible” to have accepted the high pass rates as recommended by teachers.The First Minister and education secretary John Swinney both urged pupils to appealthey feel they have been treated unfairly.Both Highland Council and Comhairle nan Eilean Siar have said overall pass rates in the region were up on the previous year

title: digging where we stand memories from the airigh shieling for a post covid new
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineOur hyper-globalised, high-octane way of le was stopped in its tracks in a matter of weeks, and many of us found ourselves confined to our local communities, with a great deal of spare time on our hands.The TaD team have – fortunately – been able to continue working from home, and over these past few months I have been lucky enough to have conversations with some of our contributors and their families, speaking about recordings from the past, but naturally reflecting on those times and comparing them with the situation we find ourselves in today.One conversation of note was with a relative of a contributor who was recorded in the early s., the ethnologist and previous TaD columnist, Mairi MacFadyen, referred to Alastair McIntosh’s idea that we should ‘dig where we stand’ in order to find meaning and to regain a ‘sense of place’.Mairi then explains: “The idea is that by researching and learning about our own history and the place we are living, we – as iniduals and as groups – can regain some control over the understanding of our lives and our inter-connectedness..”, or the shieling. – the seasonal moving of livestock and people, still practiced today in many parts of the world including the mountainous regions of Norway, Alpine and sub-Alpine Europe, and the Pyrenees.In the Highlands, the practice was widespread until the early to mid-th century when much of the moorland on which the communites had their shielings were claimed by the landowners and used for sheep runs, and for hunting., where the contributors are well aware of the custom of going to the shieling in their parents’ and grandparents’ generation... # of the sheep.Historically, this allowed the unenclosed crops in the township to grow undisturbed, and it allowed the livestock to take advantage of the superior seasonal grazing on the hills.. – the first day of may.The flitting took a lot of effort, but it was also a time full of excitement, for man and beast:., including cats for hunting the rats, but according to Donald MacDonald, dogs were not taken to the àirigh.On the first day the men would prepare the shieling huts, and the women would prepare a meal for everyone who had helped with the move, before leaving the children and younger women once everything was prepared.In Lewis the people stayed at the àirigh until the beginning of August., and they would come home at the weekends to go to church, often bringing fresh milk with them.. recited here in  by the Rev. William Matheson, a love song from Perthshire in which a woman longs to be with her sweetheart at a shieling on Rannoch Moor:We’ll get cattle from the MearnsAnd sheep from CaithnessAnd we’ll rear themOn the shieling in Rannoch MoorThere are also many songs and stories of the supernatural connected to the shielings, most likely due to their situating beyond the head dyke of the township, and the fact that they were most commonly frequented by young people and children..Another recording, of a Mrs MacLucas of Benderloch, Argyll, speaks of a forestry worker who saw a fairy woman at a shieling while working in Glen Duror.. are omnipresent in Gaelic culture, and in the Tobar an Dualchais archive, and it is clear that they were an incredibly important part of community le in some parts well into the th century – a rite of passage central to Gaelic cultural le. and from the stories and way of le of times gone by. and visit it.Imagine the hustle and bustle of the flitting, and the stories that would be told there, and welcome the new sense of place that will await you.
